Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y24-DND1-JC8G-80KY-00000-00House Panel Hears Stories of Alleged Abuse by Tech-Platform 'Giants'2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:01ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSHouse Panel Hears Stories of Alleged Abuse by Tech-Platform 'Giants'

Amazon, Apple and Google took bipartisan heat Friday in a Boulder, Colorado, field hearing on online platforms and market power, by the House Judiciary Antitrust Subcommittee. The hearing followed a discussion at CES about whether the government should break up dominant platforms (see 2001100007). The hearing was streamed from the University of Colorado Law School.

"Companies across the online ecosystem, both large and small, have found themselves dependent on the arbitrary whim of these platform giants, one algorithm tweak away from ruin," said Chairman David Cicilline, D-R.I. "It has become clear that these firms have tremendous power as gatekeepers to shape and control commerce online."

"We have seen the largest platforms continue to expand and increase their market power," raising concerns "about how that power is being used," said Rep. Ken Buck, R-Colo.Congress shouldn't forget benefits innovation has brought for consumers and that big isn't always bad, he said. "Any legislative proposals ... should be consistent with maintaining a free and competitive marketplace. Proposals to create broad new regulatory regimes must be viewed with caution. ... Burdensome regulations often miss the mark."

"The market conditions that allowed us to innovate and thrive over the past two decades are being endangered by the rise of a small group of dominant companies with unprecedented power," said Patrick Spence, CEO of smart speaker company Sonos. "We believe that this committee needs to act urgently to rein in the power of these dominant companies." The company is suing Google (see 2001070041).

Big players so dominate the market, "they have become essential business partners for every company," Spence said. Getting access to their platforms is becoming "more and more of a take it or leave it proposition." The companies have even asked Sonos to suppress its inventions, he said. "The most recent example of this is Google's refusal to allow us to use multiple voice assistants on our products simultaneously," he said: "We need to rethink existing laws and policies."

PopSockets had enormous success initially when it sold on Amazon, said David Barnett, CEO of the company, which makes removable grips for smartphones. Then, counterfeits became an issue and "we discovered that Amazon itself had sourced counterfeit product and was selling it alongside our own products," he said. "At one point, we were recording a thousand listings a day of fakes."

Amazon bullied PopSockets, Barnett said. Amazon sets the price and "they come back to us and demand funding for their lost margin when they lower their price." Barnett said at that point, the "bullying begins." PopSockets decided to end the relationship. Amazon's response "was, 'No, you're not leaving the relationship,'" he said: "I found that unbelievable ... after we told them that bullying was the main reason we were leaving." The company left anyway and Amazon removed listings of its PopSockets' resellers, he said. Other companies continue to do business with Amazon, he said: "It's because of the power asymmetry that companies tolerate this, they have to tolerate it."

"PopSockets has been a valued retail vendor at Amazon and also supplies its products directly to other major retailers," an Amazon spokesperson emailed. Like any brand, the company is "free to choose which retailers it supplies and chose to stop selling directly through Amazon. Even so, we've continued to work with PopSockets to address our shared concerns about counterfeit, and continue to have a relationship with PopSockets through Merch by Amazon, which enables other sellers to create customized PopSockets for sale."

David Hansson, chief technology officer of software company Basecamp, said that when company launched in 2004, the internet offered a largely free and open market. That's "no longer true," he said: "The internet has been colonized by a handful of big tech companies that wield their monopoly power without restraint. This power allows them to bully, extort, or, should they please, even destroy our business." Big platforms control whether "customers are able to find us online" and "can access our software using their mobile devices," Hansson said. "The promise that the internet was going to cut out the middleman has been broken."

Google has an almost complete monopoly over internet searches, Hansson said. "Their multibillion dollar bribes to browser makers like Apple ensure no fair competition will ever have a chance to emerge." With its app store, Apple owns "one of the only two mobile application stores that matter" and the other belongs to Google, he said: This "cozy duopoly" means Apple can charge "exorbitantly high" 30 percent fees for processing payments. "Help us, Congress, you are our only hope," Hansson said.

"We created the App Store with two goals in mind: that it be a safe and trusted place for customers to discover and download apps, and a great business opportunity for all developers," an Apple spokesperson emailed. "We continually work with developers and take their feedback on how to help protect user privacy while also providing the tools developers need to make the best app experiences." Google didn't comment.

Cicilline has heard too many "horror" stories from small companies that an abrupt change from one of the platforms has destroyed their business. "It is apparent that the dominant platforms are increasingly using their gatekeeper power in abusive and coercive ways," he said: "Because these platforms function as bottlenecks for online commerce, they are able to set the terms and conditions of competition, giving them immense power to pick winners and losers in the online economy."

urn:contentItem:5X23-19B1-JBM5-R1CM-00000-00House panel targets files from 4 tech giantsLawmakers impose Oct. 14 deadline for data in antitrust case2019-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:01ZLexisNexisBUSINESSAPg. 12House panel targets files from 4 tech giants
Lawmakers impose
Oct. 14 deadline for data in antitrust caseMarcy GordonAssociated Press

Rep. David Cicilline heads the subcommittee and hinted legislative changes might be needed against Big Tech.J. Scott Applewhite/AP

WASHINGTON - Lawmakers investigating the market dominance of Big Tech on Friday asked Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple for a broad range of documents, marking a step forward in Congress' bipartisan probe of the companies.

Letters went out to the four companies from the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee and its subcommittee on antitrust, which has been conducting a sweeping antitrust investigation of the companies and their impact on competition and consumers. The lawmakers are seeking a detailed and broad range of documents related to the companies' sprawling operations, including top executives' internal communications.

The move comes as scrutiny of the companies deepens and widens across the federal government and U.S. states and abroad.

The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are conducting competition investigations of the companies, and state attorneys general from both major political parties have opened antitrust investigations of Google and Facebook.

"We have to act if we see that they're breaking the law," Rohit Chopra, one of the FTC commissioners, said Friday. Chopra, a Democrat, wouldn't confirm names of companies that could be under investigation, but he said the agency is consulting with the Justice Department and the state attorneys general as their work proceeds.

Also Friday, the European Union's powerful competition chief indicated that she's looking at expanding regulations on personal data, dropping an initial hint about how she plans to use new powers against tech companies. Margrethe Vestager said that while Europeans have control over their own data through the EU's world-leading data privacy rules, they don't address problems stemming from the way companies use other people's data "to draw conclusions about me or to undermine democracy."

The House lawmakers set an Oct. 14 deadline for the companies to provide the documents.

Spokesmen for Facebook, Apple and Amazon didn't immediately respond to requests for comment Friday. Google referred to a recent blog post by its senior vice president for global affairs, Kent Walker, in which he said the company is anticipating additional questions from investigations and that "We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so."

The companies have said they'll cooperate with the congressional investigation.

Judiciary Committee Chairman Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., said the documents will help the committee understand "whether they are using their market power in ways that have harmed consumers and competition and how Congress should respond."

The letters went to the companies' CEOs: Larry Page of Google's parent company Alphabet Inc.; Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook; Jeff Bezos of Amazon; and Tim Cook of Apple. They were signed by Nadler; Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, the Judiciary Committee's senior Republican; Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., who heads the antitrust subcommittee leading the investigation; and Rep. James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, the subcommittee's senior Republican.

Cicilline has said Congress and antitrust regulators wrongly allowed the companies to regulate themselves, enabling them to operate out of control, dominating the internet and choking off online innovation and entrepreneurship. He has suggested legislative changes may be needed, though he has called breaking up the companies a last resort.

At a hearing of the antitrust panel in July, executives of the companies pushed back against lawmakers' accusations that they operate as monopolies, laying out ways in which they say they compete fairly against rivals in the marketplace.

Saying he was dissatisfied with the answers of the executives, Cicilline called the testimony "evasive."

urn:contentItem:5X22-6F31-DY37-F21Y-00000-00House panel targets files from 4 tech giantsLawmakers impose Oct. 14 deadline for data in antitrust case2019-09-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:01ZLexisNexisA SECTIONAPg. 3House panel targets files from 4 tech giants
Lawmakers impose Oct. 14 deadline for data in antitrust caseMarcy GordonAssociated Press

PHOTO: Rep. David Cicilline heads the subcommittee and hinted legislative changes might be needed against Big Tech.J. Scott Applewhite/AP

WASHINGTON - Lawmakers investigating the market dominance of Big Tech on Friday asked Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple for a broad range of documents, marking a step forward in Congress' bipartisan probe of the companies.

Letters went out to the four companies from the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee and its subcommittee on antitrust, which has been conducting a sweeping antitrust investigation of the companies and their impact on competition and consumers. The lawmakers are seeking a detailed and broad range of documents related to the companies' sprawling operations, including top executives' internal communications.

The move comes as scrutiny of the companies deepens and widens across the federal government and U.S. states and abroad.

The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are conducting competition investigations of the companies, and state attorneys general from both major political parties have opened antitrust investigations of Google and Facebook.

"We have to act if we see that they're breaking the law," Rohit Chopra, one of the FTC commissioners, said Friday. Chopra, a Democrat, wouldn't confirm names of companies that could be under investigation, but he said the agency is consulting with the Justice Department and the state attorneys general as their work proceeds.

Also Friday, the European Union's powerful competition chief indicated that she's looking at expanding regulations on personal data, dropping an initial hint about how she plans to use new powers against tech companies. Margrethe Vestager said that while Europeans have control over their own data through the EU's world-leading data privacy rules, they don't address problems stemming from the way companies use other people's data "to draw conclusions about me or to undermine democracy."

The House lawmakers set an Oct. 14 deadline for the companies to provide the documents.

Spokesmen for Facebook, Apple and Amazon didn't immediately respond to requests for comment Friday. Google referred to a recent blog post by its senior vice president for global affairs, Kent Walker, in which he said the company is anticipating additional questions from investigations and that "We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so."

The companies have said they'll cooperate with the congressional investigation.

Judiciary Committee Chairman Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., said the documents will help the committee understand "whether they are using their market power in ways that have harmed consumers and competition and how Congress should respond."

The letters went to the companies' CEOs: Larry Page of Google's parent company Alphabet Inc.; Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook; Jeff Bezos of Amazon; and Tim Cook of Apple. They were signed by Nadler; Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, the Judiciary Committee's senior Republican; Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., who heads the antitrust subcommittee leading the investigation; and Rep. James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, the subcommittee's senior Republican.

Cicilline has said Congress and antitrust regulators wrongly allowed the companies to regulate themselves, enabling them to operate out of control, dominating the internet and choking off online innovation and entrepreneurship. He has suggested legislative changes may be needed, though he has called breaking up the companies a last resort.

At a hearing of the antitrust panel in July, executives of the companies pushed back against lawmakers' accusations that they operate as monopolies, laying out ways in which they say they compete fairly against rivals in the marketplace.

Saying he was dissatisfied with the answers of the executives, Cicilline called the testimony "evasive."

WASHINGTON - Lawmakers investigating the market dominance of Big Tech on Friday asked Google, Facebook, Amazon and Apple for a broad range of documents, marking a step forward in Congress' bipartisan probe of the companies.

Letters went out to the four companies from the leaders of the House Judiciary Committee and its subcommittee on antitrust, which has been conducting a sweeping antitrust investigation of the companies and their impact on competition and consumers. The lawmakers are seeking a detailed and broad range of documents related to the companies' sprawling operations, including top executives' internal communications.

The move comes as scrutiny of the companies deepens and widens across the federal government and U.S. states and abroad.

The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are conducting competition investigations of the companies, and state attorneys general from both major political parties have opened antitrust investigations of Google and Facebook.

"We have to act if we see that they're breaking the law," Rohit Chopra, one of the FTC commissioners, said Friday. Chopra, a Democrat, wouldn't confirm names of companies that could be under investigation, but he said the agency is consulting with the Justice Department and the state attorneys general as their work proceeds.

Also Friday, the European Union's powerful competition chief indicated that she's looking at expanding regulations on personal data, dropping an initial hint about how she plans to use new powers against tech companies. Margrethe Vestager said that while Europeans have control over their own data through the EU's world-leading data privacy rules, they don't address problems stemming from the way companies use other people's data "to draw conclusions about me or to undermine democracy." The House lawmakers set an Oct. 14 deadline for the companies to provide the documents.

Spokesmen for Facebook, Apple and Amazon didn't immediately respond to requests for comment Friday. Google referred to a recent blog post by its senior vice president for global affairs, Kent Walker, in which he said the company is anticipating additional questions from investigations and that "We have always worked constructively with regulators and we will continue to do so."

The companies have said they'll cooperate with the congressional investigation.

Judiciary Committee Chairman Rep. Jerrold Nadler, D-N.Y., said the documents will help the committee understand "whether they are using their market power in ways that have harmed consumers and competition and how Congress should respond."

The letters went to the companies' CEOs: Larry Page of Google's parent company Alphabet Inc.; Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook; Jeff Bezos of Amazon; and Tim Cook of Apple. They were signed by Nadler; Rep. Doug Collins of Georgia, the Judiciary Committee's senior Republican; Rep. David Cicilline, D-R.I., who heads the antitrust subcommittee leading the investigation; and Rep. James Sensenbrenner of Wisconsin, the subcommittee's senior Republican.

Cicilline has said Congress and antitrust regulators wrongly allowed the companies to regulate themselves, enabling them to operate out of control, dominating the internet and choking off online innovation and entrepreneurship. He has suggested legislative changes may be needed, though he has called breaking up the companies a last resort.

At a hearing of the antitrust panel in July, executives of the companies pushed back against lawmakers' accusations that they operate as monopolies, laying out ways in which they say they compete fairly against rivals in the marketplace.

Saying he was dissatisfied with the answers of the executives, Cicilline called the testimony "evasive."

urn:contentItem:5RRX-S571-JC8G-91WP-00000-00House Passes FOSTA Online Sex Trafficking Bill2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:01ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSHouse Passes FOSTA Online Sex Trafficking Bill

The House passed the Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act (HR-1865) Tuesday evening on a 388-25 vote. The House approved a trio of amendments supported by lead sponsor Rep. Ann Wagner, R-Mo., amid continued opposition by some tech, privacy and open internet proponents to the possible changes. The amendments included one from Rep. Mimi Walters, R-Calif., to include language from the Stop Enabling Sex Traffickers Act (S-1693), which the House cleared on a 308-107 vote. Both bills would amend Communications Decency Act Section 230 to make it easier to bring criminal charges against websites that knowingly facilitate or promote sex trafficking. Opponents of adding the S-1693 language say HR-1865's existing language is a more targeted approach (see 1801040050).

The House approved the other two amendments on voice votes. One made "technical" changes to HR-1865's language from House Judiciary Committee Chairman Bob Goodlatte, R-Va. Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, also successfully attached an amendment that would request the GAO study civil damages and restitution orders in cases involving online sex trafficking.

House floor debate on HR-1865, like House Rules' hearing on the bill, largely supported enacting the measure. HR-1865 would "ensure that websites that unlawfully contribute to the rexploitation of sex trafficking victims are no longer immune to punishment," said Rep. Martha Roby, R-Ala., a co-sponsor of the legislation. HR-1865 "makes it clear" that Section 230 "was never intended to protect the facilitation of online prostitution or sex trafficking and calls out those websites that have acted recklessly in allowing" such activities to occur, said Jackson Lee, who also spoke in favor of the bill at the House Rules hearing.

Lofgren opposed the Walters amendment, saying including S-1693's language would "carve a hole" in Section 230 and make it actually more difficult than the underlying bill to prosecute traffickers online." Wagner defended the amendment, saying it "reinstates critical pro-victim provisions" from the original text of HR-1865. "We should not allow big tech money and special interests" to "override our criminal justice system," she said: S-1693 and HR-1865 "are two sides of the same coin and they must pass together. We need both criminal and civil tools" to effectively combat online sex trafficking. The Goodlatte and Jackson Lee amendments got unanimous support.

Tech and privacy groups from across the political spectrum urged the House Tuesday to vote down Walters' proposed addition of the S-1693 language. "The process failure here is astounding: conjoining two fundamentally incompatible bills on the House floor will harm the very people lawmakers are trying to protect," TechFreedom and Engine said. HR-1865 "was carefully crafted by [HouseJudiciary], while [S-1693] has not been reviewed by the Judiciary Committee in either chamber. Combating sex trafficking is fundamentally a law enforcement problem and demands law enforcement expertise." CTA President Gary Shapiro said an amended HR-1865 "should not be voted on by the House until [HouseJudiciary] has thoroughly reviewed it. This is highly complex legislation with significant legal implications. Deviating from regular order to rush through this bill on an artificial timetable without review could inadvertently harm lawful American entrepreneurs, small businesses and our world-leading internet economy."

Others supported including S-1693's language in HR-1865, including Facebook Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg. IBM Vice President-Government and Regulatory Affairs Christopher Padilla also wrote House leaders in support of the changes, saying the company backs "limited, controlled exceptions to the CDA immunity provision that will help policy makers, law enforcement and victims combat this kind of illicit and criminal activity on the internet."

HR-1865 "was carefully crafted by [House Judiciary], while [S-1693] has not been reviewed by the Judiciary Committee in either chamber. Combating sex trafficking is fundamentally a law enforcement problem and demands law enforcement expertise." CTA President Gary Shapiro said an amended HR-1865 "should not be voted on by the House until [House Judiciary] has thoroughly reviewed it. This is highly complex legislation with significant legal implications. Deviating from regular order to rush through this bill on an artificial timetable without review could inadvertently harm lawful American entrepreneurs, small businesses and our world-leading internet economy."

Others supported including S-1693's language in HR-1865, including Facebook Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg. IBM Vice President-Government and Regulatory Affairs Christopher Padilla also wrote House leaders in support of the changes, saying the company backs "limited, controlled exceptions to the CDA immunity provision that will help policy makers, law enforcement and victims combat this kind of illicit and criminal activity on the internet."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RRX-SM81-DXY4-X2SN-00000-00House Passes Online Sex-Trafficking Bill After Big Tech Companies Back Off2018-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:59:01ZLexisNexisBUSINESSHouse Passes Online Sex-Trafficking Bill After Big Tech Companies Back OffCecilia Kang

Silicon Valley had strongly opposed the bill because it chips away at an existing law that gives internet companies broad immunity.

The House on Tuesday passed a bill that gives victims and prosecutors more power to sue websites that knowingly aided sex trafficking, adding a new level of accountability for internet companies.

Silicon Valley had strongly opposed the bill, because it would chip away at an existing law that gives internet companies broad immunity for the content that people put on their services. Tech companies that argued against the bill said that the current law has encouraged free speech online and helped the internet thrive.

But sex trafficking victims and law enforcement officials say the existing law, known as Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, has been too loosely applied by sites like Backpage.com, a site known for prostitution and sex trafficking. Some large online companies, including Facebook, eventually backed off from their opposition to the bill after its scope was narrowed.

“Congress never intended for the internet to be a haven for criminal activity,” said Representative Ann Wagner, a Missouri Republican who introduced the bill, known as the Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act. “This is not a slippery slope. It is a narrow amendment to stop crimes by businesses online that they weren’t able to commit offline.”

A similar bill in the Senate was expected to pass soon.

The new legislation would not affect most internet companies. A victim would need to prove a site had knowingly facilitated sex trafficking to successfully sue the company. But not all online companies could hide behind the Section 230 shield.

The bill’s passage in the House signaled an important turning point for an industry that has largely operated free of regulations. Pressure has been mounting for social media companies and other internet giants to be better stewards of their powerful platforms.

Facebook, in particular, has come under pressure over the spread of misinformation and the exertion of foreign interference during the 2016 presidential election. Democratic and Republican lawmakers have called for regulations, including disclosures on political advertising, but those efforts have been slow to gain wide support.

“Clearly the environment has changed a lot for big internet companies over the past year,” said Paul Gallant, a tech and telecom industry analyst at Cowen & Co. “But I still don’t think there is a willingness for the government to pursue fundamental business model changes.”

Facebook began to change its position on the bill last fall, before congressional hearings on sex-trafficking bills and an intelligence committee hearing on Russian influence on social networks.

“We all have a responsibility to do our part to fight this,” Facebook’s chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, wrote in a post on the site this week. “We at Facebook support efforts to pass amended legislation in the House that would allow responsible companies to continue fighting sex trafficking while giving victims the chance to seek justice against companies that knowingly facilitate such abhorrent acts.”

Some large tech companies, including Oracle, IBM and HP, have supported the new legislative effort all along. But many start-ups, including those represented by Engine Advocacy, a trade group, remained opposed to the bills.

Engine Advocacy said part of the bill would hurt start-ups that lean heavily on user-generated content, and could lead Congress to take more actions to weaken the openness of the internet.

PHOTO: “Congress never intended for the internet to be a haven for criminal activity,” said Representative Ann Wagner of Missouri, who introduced the Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act. (PHOTOGRAPH BY Al Drago/The New York Times FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Related Articles

Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington

In Reversal, Tech Companies Back Sex Trafficking Bill

Alcee Hastings (D-FL) Votes In Favor Of Impeachment Rules Resolution; Morrison Testimony; NSC Official Tim Morrison Says He Didn't Think Anything Improper Was Discussed On The Trump- Ukraine Call; Morrison Told Investigators Did Not Believe Ukrainians Had Knowledge Of Military Aid Being On Hold; Tough On China; Dangerous Wildfires; Profits Fall; Fed Gets It Wrong; 5G Rollout; China's State Telecoms To Launch 5G Services On Friday; Pompeo Slams Communist China In Speech; The Real Collusion; State Deparmentt Docs; Obama State Dept Official In Contact W/ Russian Embassy One Month Before Trump InaugurationLou Dobbs, John Roberts, Catherine Herridge, Tammy Bruce

LOU DOBBS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good evening everybody. The Radical Dems have completed their effort to formalize their efforts to overthrow the president of the United States.

The vote in the House, 232 to 196. All of the two of those Radical Dems today voted to approve the so-called rules by which they will carry on their proceedings against the president.

After 37 days of secrecy and subversion the Radical Dems voted to now make their unprecedented secret assault against this president public. But not -- not before they hold more secret hearings over the next week.

Republicans protested, but could do little more than vote no. And that closed 232 to 196 vote means the Radical Dems have a clear statement that impeachment should never have been attempted in the House.

Not a single Republican broke ranks. Every one of them voted against the bill. Two Democrats joined the Republicans in their opposition. And the party of hate has cheated and lied throughout in their efforts to subvert President Trump.

All the while, the president is doing what he has always done. He's working. He's pressing ahead with his agenda and perhaps even under his breath cussing Pelosi, Schiff and the rest. Let's go to Chief White House Correspondent John Roberts at the White House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: President Trump dismissed today's vote on the resolution as more posturing by Democrats, ripping them in a radio appearance with the U.K.'s Nigel Farage.

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: The Democrats are desperate. They are desperate. They have nothing. And it's the only way they're going to try and win the election this way because they can't win it the fair way.

ROBERTS: While the White House had said it would not cooperate with the inquiry until House Speaker Pelosi held a vote in the full House cooperation apparently is still not forthcoming. White House official saying, the resolution does not ensure due process for the president.

STEPHANIE GRISHAM, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: We don't know the rules yet for the White House. Are we going to get to even be involved? I don't think so.

ROBERTS: Democrats insist the new guidelines do allow the president and his council to participate, but not until the third phase of the inquiry after it has been referred to the Judiciary Committee.

And even then the president's involvement is subject to the discretion of the chairman. This afternoon, President Trump summoned House GOP members to the White House to discuss next steps while communications staff briefed surrogates on what they call the impeachment sham.

The message from the White House. That it's President Trump who was working on behalf of the country, not Democrats. A new Associated Press poll tonight finds that the president's support among Republicans is holding steady.

Eighty-five percent of Republicans approved of the president's handling of the job. Overall his job approval rating stands at 42 percent. Lou?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: John, thank you very much. John Roberts, from the White House. President Trump's strong approval ratings among the Republican Party show in today's vote with every present Republican member of congress voting against the Dems' sham, impeachment rules resolution.

Of the 232 Democrats who voted in favor of today's motion, 79 of them are from 21 states that President Trump won in 2016. Think about that. And on an average, President Trump won those states by a margin of almost 14 percent.

A notable yes vote today came from Congressman Alcee Hastings. Hastings himself was impeached by the senate for accepting bribes in exchange for lenient sentences during his time as a federal judge in Florida.

It was seemed today's Democratic Party however is short of the historical need to impeach President Trump. For historical context, the House voted 228-206 in favor of impeaching President Clinton for perjury, 221 to 212 for obstruction of justice in October 1998.

President Nixon's impeachment inquiry however was certainly bipartisan. Formally ratified in the House in February of '74 by a margin of 410 to four.

And in February, 18 to 68 the House voted 126 to 47 in favor of a resolution to impeach President Andrew Johnson. Only Nixon did not survive those votes.

While votes were taken today in Congress, the Dems' shadowy inquiry continued. National Security Council Official, Tim Morrison was on Capitol Hill, there he answered questions from lawmakers behind closed doors, of course.

But it appears he delivered a major blow against the left's narrative of improper behavior by President Trump during that July phone call with the leader of Ukraine. Chief Intelligence Correspondent Catherine Herridge with the report.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CATHERINE HERRIDGE, FOX NEWS CHIEF INTELLIGENCE CORRESPONDENT: Lou, a top National Security Council official with first-hand knowledge of the phone call told investigators that he didn't think anything improper or illegal was discussed on the call and he thought the publicly released transcript was complete.

According to this prepared remarks obtained by Fox News, Tim Morrison said he had immediate concerns the transcript would leak. How it would play out in Washington's polarized environment and how a leak would affect bipartisan support for Ukraine as well as how it would affect the Ukrainian perception of the U.S.

In addition, he said quote, I want to be clear. I was not concerned that anything illegal was discussed. Morrison told investigators he had no reason to believe the Ukrainians had knowledge the military aid was on hold until the end of August when the Politico story was published.

And he had no reason to believe the release of it might be conditioned on a public statement about re-opening an investigation into the Ukraine energy firm where Joe Biden's son sat on the board until weeks after the call.

Morrison's testimony about the call transcript as complete appears to undercut Lieutenant Colonel Alexander Vindman who reportedly questioned whether it was tampered with.

A source close to the deposition today said, Morrison also warned about Vindman's judgment. And on at least one occasion he said, Vindman went outside the chain of command on Ukraine. Lou?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Thank you very much. Catherine Herridge, reporting. Our first guest tonight was in today's closed door deposition of Tim Morrison.

And joining us now is Congressman Scott Perry. He's a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Congressman, good to have you with us.

REP. SCOTT PERRY (R-PA), HOUSE FOREIGN AFFAIRS COMMITTEE: Great to be here with you, Lou.

DOBBS: To the degree that you can, give us your sense of Morrison's testimony and its potential damage or support of the president.

PERRY: Well, I would say this. First of all, the Democrats keep on saying, well you won't talk about, but you Republicans won't talk about the substance, you just want to talk about process.

We can talk about substance because it would be an ethics violation. But let me say this, today was a -- was a very positive day for Republicans, and Adam Schiff's Star Chamber.

The folks there had a very sour face. It's interesting, we finished up our deposition early today and I think that's an indicator of how fast they wanted to get that guy out of -- out of the room because he obliterated their narrative. And you will see it I think at some point, it's going to take a while, but you will see what he said at some point.

DOBBS: To the degree you can, give us some sense of this process --

PERRY: Yeah.

DOBBS: -- today, they formalized a process, but it certainly doesn't legitimize anything. And moving forward, what are we to expect? We've got a sense that there will be more secret hearings. When does a public process begin and will it ever be put forward without the approval of Adam Schiff.

PERRY: Well, first of all, as your White House reporter said, the president and more due process doesn't really happen until phase three until it gets to judiciary.

So, imagine playing a baseball game where the opponent gets three strikes but you only get two. And you know, you only get to -- you only get to hit with half a bat until the 9th inning. That's the process they just approved today.

So, while they are saying that you can call witnesses and you can have counsel president, that's the discretion of Chairman Schiff. And I would just remind everybody that while we've been in the SCIF (ph), when we have gone to questions regarding the intelligence community, he has said that is off limits.

Now, think about this, this is the chairman of the Intelligence Community we're in the Intelligence Community scif and he won't allow the minority have to ask questions about the intelligence community's involvement in the proceedings and these accusations.

That's what we're facing. So, it's going to be a continued situation where they are setting the table, a narrative that supports their objective, which is to defeat the president or impeach the president. It is not about fairness, it is not about justice. It's not about due process.

DOBBS: It is about wasting a lot of time and distracting from issues that this president must deal with. The House frankly, the Radical Dems have the luxury of not having to take care of any business other than to assault this president which they've done from the moment -- the moment he was elected in point of fact, not just simply inaugurated.

PERRY: Well, we've got -- we've got North Korea firing missiles. We could be passing the USMCA. We could be doing prescription drug reform. We could be doing infrastructure.

There are issues that the American people are very interested in. If Nancy -- if Speaker Pelosi and the Democrats want to spend their majority chasing this president around trying to do anything to impeach him, that's their business.

Unfortunately, the country gets dragged through with them. It is really unfortunate and irresponsible in my opinion.

DOBBS: Yeah. I have to say, I didn't detect any sincerity at all. Perhaps, that was a mistake of my perception on the part of the speaker when she suggested that the Dems would be prayerful over this somber process. I did not see that somber attitude whatsoever.

PERRY: Well, Lou, if you were on the floor you would have heard them at the end of the vote, their members telling their other members not to cheer.

So, you need to be coached not to cheer because to them, this is what they've been seeking all along. And, of course, you don't see that if you're watching from home, but that's what we witnessed right there on the House floor. So sincerity I think is in question in this case.

DOBBS: Congressman, thanks for being with us. We appreciate it.

PERRY: Thank you so much. Thank you.

DOBBS: Congressman Scott Perry. Up next, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo reveals a new strategy on how the United States is dealing with China. We take that up with Dr. Michael Pillsbury. Also tonight, Secretary Pompeo holding forth on a number of foreign policy issues. We're coming right back. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Welcome back. Coming up on this broadcast, Congressman Mark Meadows joins us on the Radical Dems' efforts to formalize proceedings they can't legitimize against president. Also, where are we with the U.S.-China trade deal? Dr. Michael Pillsbury joins us tonight with that.

On Wall Street, stocks closing lower. The DOW Jones Industrials fell 140 points. The S&P down, nine and the NASDAQ lost 12. Volume on the big board, moderate trading.

Crude oil closing flat over $4 a barrel. Gold gained three percent. Silver up six and a half percent. Gold and silver surging on investor anxiety about the trade deal between the United States and China.

Apple profits shrinking for a fourth consecutive quarter. The longest streak since 2016, profits fell three percent under $14 billion. Apple shares however, still trading two percent higher in after hours.

And the jobs report to be released tomorrow. Economists expecting about 75,000 jobs were added in October, down from 136,000 the previous month. The unemployment rate at three and a half percent, a 50-year low.

President Trump claims the Radical Dems are hurting the markets with their impeachment inquiry, so-called. Wall Street strategist say that isn't solved.

Now, I wonder who these strategists are. They are surely the same strategist who said tariffs would tariff our economy and these markets. These are strategists investors should in my judgment, probably not listen to.

President Trump today also sliming the fed after it cut interest rates for a third time this year, the president tweeted this, quote, people are very disappointed in Jay Powell and the Federal Reserve.

The fed has called it wrong from the beginning, too fast, too slow. We are now by far the biggest and strongest country, but the fed puts us at a competitive advantage.

The president referring to the strength of the dollar and what that means to U.S. exports to the world. A reminder to listen to my reports three times a day coast to coast on the Salem Radio Network.

Joining us tonight, Congressman Mark Meadows, member of the House Oversight Committee and member of the Freedom Caucus. Congressman, great to have you with us. And let's --

REP. MARK MEADOWS (R-NC), HOUSE OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE: Great to be back with you, Lou.

DOBBS: These secret Star Chamber proceedings that you are -- I guess the world is witnessing, since you can't exercise any full participation in them, give us your assessment of what happened today, the witness and your reaction to his testimony.

MEADOWS: Well, I think the Democrats called Mr. Morrison in to be one of their star witnesses believing that they would back up -- or be would back up their claim that the president used leverage with A, the Ukraine for something in return.

What we now know is not only was he not their star witness, but he turned out to be one of the best witnesses for the president and for the American people that we could have asked for.

I can tell you, early on, you know, a lot of my Democratic colleagues were just fidgeting in their seats. Their body language was one that showed disapproval of his testimony.

Because what he was doing was backing up the president of the United States. And you mentioned that we don't get to participate. It's interesting. We had a vote today on the House floor as you well know.

DOBBS: Right. Yeah.

MEADOWS: But I had to come out of an impeachment hearing in the basement, one that's been closed off to the cameras and to your viewers in order to vote for an impeachment vote.

You know, come on, the Democrats are craved to impeach this president and upset the votes and the will of the American people from November 2016.

DOBBS: It's stunning to watch this. And I -- and you to be there as it's unfolding against all reason. This vote and 196 Republicans standing fast and behind his president. That augurs poorly for these Radical Dems' and this specious effort to attack the president.

He calls it the greatest witch hunt ever. It is that, but he is -- by the way, he's gone through so many witch hunts. It's hard to pick the worst of the bunch.

MEADOWS: Well, here's the interesting thing is, we got some of the same players today that are working in this witch hunt that worked in the previous one.

You know, the rest -- the first one was the Russia hoax. Now, we have the Ukraine fairytale. And we've got the same players, its Adam Schiff and all of his group of individuals putting forth a narrative to spin it out to the American people, leak it out to the American people so that they believe something is happening behind closed doors that in fact, is not happening.

So, I'm here today to say let's put the deposition we just heard over the last seven hours behind closed doors. Let's put it out to the American people tonight.

If we do that, I can tell you, will have Democrats peeling off left and right. They will start to go the other way and they will say, you know what, it's time that we focus on 2020. Let them get their nominee. Let us go with President Donald J. Trump. I like our chances.

DOBBS: So do I. As a matter of fact, it is becoming I think increasingly clear that the Republicans are gaining rapidly an advantage over the Democratic Party in 2020. The president -- this party united behind him. I frankly -- I think the Democrats are in far more trouble than they can possibly imagine.

MEADOWS: Well they are. And you know why, Lou? Because this president has done what he campaigned on. I mean, that's why the Democrats are going crazy is because, this president campaigned on exactly what he's doing.

The economy is roaring, he's building the wall. He put the embassy in Jerusalem. He's making sure that regulations are cut. He's making sure that the hard-working American taxpayer actually get to keep more of their money. And he's done all of that. So it's promises kept. And I can tell you, that's driving the left crazy.

DOBBS: It is. And by the way, he also has unemployment down to a level not seen in a half century. Minorities in this country at record-low unemployment rates. And he didn't create a single new federal program.

He didn't require hundreds of billions of dollars to spread out across the country to get those jobs. These are driven jobs -- job creation driven by a pro business, a leader who actually believes in this free enterprise capitalist system of ours.

MEADOWS: Well, you're exactly right, Lou. He knows the American people are smart. And, you know, if you get out of the way and let them achieve the American dream, it's available for all of us. You've lived it, I lived it. We've been able to see so many other people lifted out of poverty.

But what happens is, it's not about another government program. It's about reducing government's role in our daily lives and allowing us to enjoy the prosperity of our hard work. And we need to put the value back in hard work and I believe this president is doing that.

DOBBS: Value and respect.

MEADOWS: Yeah.

DOBBS: Thank you very much congressman for all you're doing.

MEADOWS: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Congressman Mark Meadows.

MEADOWS: Thank you.

DOBBS: Up next. Optimism from the White House at a trade deal with China will still be signed, but what progress has been made in those talks with China? We'll take that up with Dr. Michael Pillsbury. He joins me right after these messages. Stay with us.

DOBBS: China's three state telecoms announcing that they've launched their 5G services as of today, ahead of the scheduled launch early next year.

China plans to install over 50,000 5G base stations across 50 Chinese cities by the end of this year. Currently, 10,000 5G stations are up and running in Beijing.

Telecom Huawei says it has already signed more than 60 commercial contracts to supply 5G networks around the world. The United States is lagging.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo delivered a passionate speech last night the Hudson Institute in New York. He slammed the communist Chinese regime amid ongoing trade talks between the United States and Beijing.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE: The communist government in China today is not the same as the people of China. They are reaching for and using methods that have created challenges for the United States and for the world.

And we collectively, all of us need to confront these challenges from the PRC head on. It's no longer realistic to ignore the fundamental differences between our two systems.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: And joining us tonight to take up that issue and many others, Dr. Michael Pillsbury. He's director of the Center for Chinese Strategy at the Hudson Institute.

MICHAEL PILLSBURY, HUDSON INSTITUTE CHINESE STRATEGY DIRECTOR: Hi.

DOBBS: Mike, good to have you here.

PILLSBURY: Thanks Lou.

DOBBS: Listening to the secretary of state, he sound like a man who meant exactly what he's saying.

PILLSBURY: Yes, I think so. There's a lot of toughness in the speech. I particularly noticed his use of the phrase, the freedom-loving Chinese people.

He's going -- he's trying to create a wedge between the Chinese Communist Party leaders and the Chinese people. He had several references to loving Chinese-Americans inside our country as well.

It's already -- as I've said, the Chinese ambassador to Washington who has reacted very -- I would say viciously to this. And attacked what Secretary Pompeo was saying because according to Chinese Communist Party and the ambassador who's a member, all of China's success is due to the Communist Party.

So, how narrow Secretary Pompeo tried to draw a wedge between the Communist Party and the freedom-loving Chinese people. That was a quite effective comment he made.

DOBBS: Effective comment and obviously a designed and carefully considered comment. And without question, with the -- with the foreknowledge of what the reaction on the part of the Chinese would be.

PILLSBURY: Yes.

DOBBS: This is not looking good. The Chinese sending out signals for whoever's consumption that they are not pleased with the thought or comfortable with the thought that they would buy $40 to $50 billion of agricultural products.

PILLSBURY: Yes.

DOBBS: As they had earlier indicated they would. And this seems to be an impediment to phase one or perhaps to any deal at all. And it also seems to be again, the Chinese reneging on a deal that has not been put to paper yet.

PILLSBURY: Yes. The president had said quite clearly two weeks ago that he expected these purchases of agricultural products to begin immediately. Put it on all caps letter in his tweet.

What is happening I think Lou, if we look back over the last couple years, the Chinese have to -- have had to be dragged kicking and screaming into these talks, then they agree to 150 pages reneged on a lot of that.

Now, what both Steve Mnuchin and Peter Navarro have said, I believe it's correct. One of the seven chapters of the agreement has been more or less agreed to. That's what the president meant today when he said, 60 percent of the deal will be in this phase one. Then he wants to sign it within two weeks.

But the Chinese have continued to resist. They mobilize what Secretary Pompeo very, very frankly today, perhaps picking up from the theme of yours, Lou on the show. He used the terms, lobbyists for China, China lobbyists in Washington, D.C., and American business --

DOBBS: Yeah.

PILLSBURY: -- have made it very difficult for to us come to terms with the level of hostility from China toward our country.

DOBBS: And there's no reason for this administration, this president, his administration to rationalize it further. This is an inescapable confrontation on the part of the Chinese.

It is not an accident they are reneging in the last moments of the May withdrawal, from what is perceived to be an agreement. And this is not an accident.

It's -- and there has been no diminishment whatsoever of their cyber- attacks, of their intellectual property theft, of their trade theft and espionage against this country during this process that was leading up, we had hoped and understandably so would result in a deal with China.

PILLSBURY: Well --

DOBBS: It appears that deal is hanging by a thread, if you will.

PILLSBURY: I think what you see if you examine Vice President Mike Pence's speech a few days ago, with Mike Pompeo's last night, you see a new tactic by the president that he's written about in art of the deal.

He's offering kind of an olive branch to these two speeches. Vice President Pence said that we -- we don't want decoupling of our businesses from China. We don't want to contain China.

Secretary Pompeo almost politically said we don't want a confrontation with China. So, they are trying to calm down the rhetoric of the first two years that China is a mortal threat to our country.

This might work. It's a process of shaping the Chinese over the next two weeks. We only can't their signature on the agreement, because then the enforcement mechanism began to kick in for intellectual property theft. That's the good news.

DOBBS: And December 1st also, there will be apparently --

PILLSBURY: Right.

DOBBS: -- an effort by the Chinese. They have paved the way to --

PILLSBURY: Right.

DOBBS: -- to legitimately in their view take every American company's data, files, whatever maybe contained therein for themselves. I mean, this is outrageous, Mike.

PILLSBURY: Yes, it is. And it's worse than that. The Chinese have a full court press now through our businessmen, our billionaires, our media, some people inside the Trump administration to cancel all the tariffs in December.

DOBBS: Yeah.

PILLSBURY: That's what the Chinese want. And they claimed, they may be bluffing. I think they are bluffing. But their idea is we will walk out of these trade talks if you don't take all of these tariffs off of us.

DOBBS: Yeah. The louder they squeal, I think, it's an interesting signal to try to interpret.

PILLSBURY: Yes.

DOBBS: I would like to get your view on something that seems to me to have escaped the Chinese surely after being too clever. They may push this president into doing exactly the thing that will insure even greater public support. And that is, take a hard line against the Chinese who are treating the United States with such abject disrespect.

PILLSBURY: That's the risk they are taking. I fear that the Chinese are underestimating President Trump's determination. I told him myself on several trips, to look back on his book in the year 2000 when he has a long section on China, the major challenge to America. And they're not going to get ahead of America on his watch.

DOBBS: Yeah.

PILLSBURY: So they just don't believe it. They have too many other sources apparently here in Washington telling them that Trump is only bluffing.

DOBBS: Well, they have, yeah.

PILLSBURY: He doesn't mean it, this kind of thing.

DOBBS: The unregistered foreign agents at the Wall Street, and the Chamber of Commerce, the business roundtable and other savants of the nations --

PILLSBURY: Secretary Pompeo came pretty close to calling them out last night when he said, Chinese got this.

DOBBS: I was watching him march right up to that. And I was waiting for it. Michael, I appreciate it. Michael Pillsbury.

PILLSBURY: Thanks, Lou.

DOBBS: Thank you much. We'd like your thoughts on all of this. Share your comments, follow me on Twitter @LouDobbs, like me on Facebook, follow me on Instagram @LouDobbsTonight.

Up next, a new bombshell showing the Obama administration colluding with Russia just a month before President Trump's inauguration? What are you talking about? We'll tell you next.

And testimony from a former White House official goes bad for the Dems. We'll be right back with that story and much more. Stay with us.

DOBBS: Documents now reveal that an Obama State Department official, Jonathon Wiener was in contact with a Russian embassy political chief one month before Donald Trump's inauguration as president.

The material obtained by Judicial Watch also shows that State Department officials continued to use unsecure Blackberries for the transmission of classified material a year after Hillary Clinton's use of her unsecured server had been discovered.

Joining us tonight is Christian Whiton. He's a senior fellow at the Center for National Interest, Former State Department Senior Advisor in both the Trump and George W. Bush administrations.

Chris, it's good to have you with us. Let's start with the Judicial Watch documents. This is stunning stuff. And that document is how important, do you believe?

CHRISTIAN WHITON, CENTER FOR THE NATIONAL INTEREST SENIOR FELLOW: You know, I think it was. It pertained to points that were being generated for the Foreign Minister Lavrov, Russia's foreign minister.

So the implication being, John Kerry may have been preparing to speak with Lavrov in the whining days of his tenure at the State Department, and this was very classified and it was forwarded on unclassified systems.

This is sort of left over where I guess if you're a Democrat or one of these deep state critters, it's okay to break the law and do that, not if you're Republican, they'll throw the book at you.

But it also raise a serious question, again, and frankly, it raises more questions than it answers because we still don't know sort of the true access of Christopher Steele and the fake dossier on Donald Trump that was totally phony and how that came to be. But it looks like State Department officials may have played a role in that.

DOBBS: And Jonathan Wiener appears to have played a key role as Steele's conduit to the diplomats. And that seems important here as we are now starting to look at where the real collusion was taking place and with whom.

WHITON: Right. Why was he -- why were they connecting with senior officials at the Russian embassy? I mean, Wiener's job was supposed to be about Libya.

DOBBS: Right.

WHITON: So, what was the role here? And frankly, it raises questions about Russia's role. I mean, the left have sort of assumed that Russia is trying to help Donald Trump win even though it was feckless and played no real role in doing even though it tried.

But who knows. Maybe there are elements in Russia who really were in on those conspiracy to stage a coup against the elected president of the United States.

DOBBS: Wouldn't that be something because the collusion now, it seems to be decidedly tilting toward the other party, if you will. It's unclear whom, if there is indeed collusion of any kind.

It's deeply troubling to watch this process of the Dems which they formalized today. But they can't legitimize so I'm not sure exactly what they had -- they think they're doing.

But don't they -- don't the Dems have a bit of a problem? They bring in Tim Morrison. We're hearing very clearly that Tim Morrison who resigned his post at the White House was absolutely supportive of the president and very candid about his judgment of that phone call.

WHITON: Right. And Tim has a lot of credibility. Tim is a friend of mine. He served with Former Senator Jon Kyle, in the senate as his aide. And then on the House Armed Services Committee before going to the NSC, I don't know why, Tim resigned.

But it may have just been because of conflicting advice on to whether he should or should not testify. And he spent a lot of time on Capitol Hill. But anyway, the result was not what the Democrats hoped for.

He is what -- unlike a lot of these deep state cry babies who were out there saying, oh, Donald Trump cut us out on the process on Ukraine or he didn't take my brilliant advice on Russia.

Tim was actually on the phone call. One of the few people in this mix who were and he said there was nothing illegal in that call. Of course, we already know that from the transcript. But it's nice to have a first-hand witness re-affirm that.

DOBBS: It is. And like you said, we do have a transcript and we just learned that Tim Morrison's last day on the job will be tomorrow, Chris. The -- then let's turn to this Colonel Vindman. He is an interesting fellow in large measure because of his opening statement.

In which he talked about the interagency. You talked about the consensus of the interagency and he actually was informing people what the National Security Council would abide and what it would not.

This is a man who has a very high opinion of this monolith that's rising out of the swamp called the interagency in a very low opinion of the constitution which does give foreign policy to the president to carry out.

WHITON: Yeah. What we have here is a collection of the palace units who have decided they know better than the emperor and would prefer rule in his place.

The interagency process is just a collection of bureaucrats from across the agent -- from across various national security agencies. And so you just have to ask yourself, who sets foreign policy? The constitution says the president does.

And I think most Americans think the person they elected, the president does, but you have these critters like -- what is it with these lieutenant colonels who come out of nowhere who want to have World War III with Russia.

Reminds me of Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Peters who, of course, you know, thinks Putin is worse than Hitler and wants to start World War III. But, you know, what this is, is really rank insubordination.

This isn't whistle blowing. You just said, what? I have feelings. I feel Donald Trump is doing something unethical. Donald Trump had no idea who this guy was four or five days ago.

DOBBS: Christian Whiton, we know who you are and we appreciate you being with us. Thanks so much.

WHITON: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Christian Whiton. Senator Mike Lee doesn't want you to know about his bill that would accelerate the flow of Indian H-1B visa workers into the United States, putting all of the progress for the American middle class and workers at peril.

Yesterday, Senator Dick Durbin called for a further look into Lee's Senate Bill 386 known as the, quote, Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act. Think -- when was the last time we saw a fairness for the middle class and American workers act?

Well, this bill already passed in the House as HR 1044. The bill is supported by the Indian government as well as big tech firms like Google and Microsoft. Do I need to tell you more? Today, Lee objected and wants to work it out with Durbin behind closed doors.

(BEGIN VIDEO TAPE)

SEN. MIKE LEE (R-UT): I don't believe that any further factual development concerning this bill is necessary. Indeed, at this point, I believe a hearing can serve no purpose other than to delay speedy action on this important reform.

(END VIDEO TAPE)

DOBBS: In Lee's judgment, obviously he thinks the bill is so important that it should pass in the dark of night with unanimous consent which would not require a vote by a single senator.

Durbin is trying to save his hide and the American worker perhaps, perhaps by objecting and they want to work together to avoid a hearing. You know, the public. That messy bunch of voters we all represent.

They want to do it in the dark of night without our witnessing what's happening and who is doing what to this country. Senate Bill 386, we're going to watch. We may not have any influence at all. But I hope the president of the United States stands up against this and tells them to withdraw that bill.

It's ignorance, it is utter hypocrisy and needs not advance at all. Up next, the hypocrisy of the radical left's impeachment resolution. We take it up with Tammy Bruce right after this quick break. Stay with us, we're coming right back.

DOBBS: House Speaker Pelosi today, called the Dems' sham impeachment inquiry the sworn duty of congress. Here's what she had to say on the floor of the House.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SPEAKER OF THE UNITED STATES HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVE: Nobody, I doubt anybody in this place, or anybody that you know comes to congress to take the oath of office, comes to congress to impeach the president of the United States unless his actions are jeopardizing our honoring our oath of office.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Pelosi forgot about Congresswoman Tlaib, Rashida Tlaib said these just hours after she was sworn into office.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. RASHIDA TLAIB (D-MI): When your son looks at you and says, mama, look, you won. Please don't win. And I said, baby they don't because we're going to go in there, we're going to teach them --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DOBBS: Another of Pelosi's caucus members, Congressman Al Green, he has also tried and failed three times in two years, to get the House to vote on impeachment.

The last time, back in July. It was rejected 332 to 95. Well, joining us now, Tammy Bruce, Washington Times columnist, Fox Business Contributor, the host of Fox Nations Get, Tammy Bruce, great to have you with us.

TAMMY BRUCE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Hey there. Good evening.

DOBBS: Let's start with this process. And the Radical Dems seem to have - - I guess, the word is unhinged. They have really lost sight of what they are doing here and the consequences I can only believe.

BRUCE: Well, we've seen that from the start for quite some time now. So this is not a one off, it's not a surprise. We've seen it, of course, in their reaction during the campaign. Certainly, right after -- the day after -- well, the day of the inaugural.

It was the headline I think of the Washington Post about now, the impeachment begins. So the American people have seen this bizarre kind of activity meant to, of course, negate their vote, to negate their existence and their importance.

DOBBS: They have been trying to overthrow this president since 2016. They have done so openly and they have -- and the national media have sort supported that posture by saying, they've Trump's derangement syndrome, the poor babies can't get over the election results.

And all I can think when I hear that crap is asking two candidates, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump whether they would accept the results of the election. And Clinton was absolutely sure about the facts she could have accept it.

BRUCE: Yes, of course. And look, I've said this before to my radio audience, and I think it's worth repeating. That this impeachment dynamic is expected.

That it would actually be necessary if we were correct in 2016 because Donald Trump's election was in large part because we knew something was wrong with Washington.

That they had stopped listening to us. That we became like collateral damage in their games. That we needed a disrupter. Someone who would make the difference and so we get the Russia hoax dossier, but now, of course, we would have an impeachment.

DOBBS: The insurance policy.

BRUCE: Well, yes. And I would -- and, of course, they will impeach him. It's the ends justify the means. But we have to realize that this confirms that we were correct in 2016. I believe the president understands that and this is part and parcel of what we have to expect as we clean out the dumpster fire of Washington, D.C.

And I'm looking forward to it and when you see it with that perspective it makes sense. And it's heartbreaking, but the founders set us up with a system that allows to us make sure that these kinds of shenanigans don't succeed.

DOBBS: Yeah, I would quibble with you on only a part. And that is that we needed any validation whatsoever that we have chosen the right person to lead the country.

When you look at everything he has done, in three years he's a historic president. What's wrong with this country? As you correctly state, we sensed, we thought, we suspected what was going on with this country, but we had no idea. How bad --

BRUCE: And boy, did we get proof. Did we get proof.

DOBBS: Tammy Bruce, we'll be with us right after this quick break. Stay with us, we're coming right back.

DOBBS: We're back with Tammy Bruce. And Tammy, what we're watching in Washington is disgusting. The Radical Dems are appalling. It's a polarized country. But the fact of the matter is, it's evident, who the bad actors are here and their names are Pelosi and Schiff and the list goes on.

BRUCE: It couldn't be more clear. And you know what it is, it's a call to courage for the American people. Especially those who may have been on the edge and don't know. But it's a good time to be alive. It's a good time to be us. And we have a challenge and we're up for it.

DOBBS: And that challenge is, president -- and it is a clear and present danger. I don't think as I said a few times, calling it a hoax, calling it a witch hunt. I almost trivialize --

BRUCE: I agree.

DOBBS: -- the mortal combat that we're engaged in, in the swamp. Tammy Bruce, always great to have you with us.

BRUCE: Thank you, Lou.

DOBBS: Thanks so much. Appreciate it. That's it for us tonight. Thanks for joining us. See you tomorrow night, right here, pretty please. Good night from New York.
