House Small Business Committee Holds Hearing On Big Tech'S Impact On Small Business

November 14, 2019 01:00 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

REP. NYDIA M. VELAZQUEZ (D-N.Y.), CHAIRWOMAN

REP. ABBY FINKENAUER (D-IOWA)

REP. JARED GOLDEN (D-MAINE)

REP. ANDY KIM (D-N.J.)

REP. JASON CROW (D-COLO.)

REP. SHARICE DAVIDS (D-KAN.)

REP. JUDY CHU (D-CALIF.)

REP. MARC VEASEY (D-TEXAS)

REP. DWIGHT EVANS (D-PA.)

REP. BRAD SCHNEIDER (D-ILL.)

REP. ADRIANO ESPAILLAT (D-N.Y.)

REP. ANTONIO DELGADO (D-N.Y.)

REP. CHRISSY HOULAHAN (D-PA.)

REP. STEVE CHABOT (R-OHIO), RANKING MEMBER

REP. AUMUA AMATA COLEMAN RADEWAGEN (R-A.S.)

REP. TRENT KELLY (R-MISS.)

REP. TROY BALDERSON (R-OHIO)

REP. KEVIN HERN (R-OKLA.)

REP. JIM HAGEDORN (R-MINN.)

REP. PETE STAUBER (R-MINN.)

REP. TIM BURCHETT (R-TENN.)

REP. ROSS SPANO (R-FLA.)

REP. JOHN JOYCE (R-PA.)

[*]VELAZQUEZ: Good afternoon. The committee will come to order. And I want to take this opportunity to thank everyone for joining us today. I would like to start by thanking all our witnesses for coming to the table today to participate in this hearing including those that travelled. And in particular, I want to thank Amazon and Google for deciding to appear today. I know that this was not an easy decision for your company but I believe it was the right one.

As everyone can see, we also have two empty chairs to demonstrate the failure of Facebook and Apple. Companies that somehow find the means to spend millions on lobbying and hire dozens of executives to find the time to be here today. Their failure to appear not only impedes Congress mission but also speaks volumes about the company's commitment to transparency and their very own customers.

So, yes, thank you Amazon and Google for being here today, and to Facebook and Apple, you reap what you sow. It is important that everyone in the room understands that this committee has a tradition of being fair and that will continue during this hearing.

Earlier this year, we held a hearing on how the digital ecosystem promotes entrepreneurship. And last year, we held an Amazon roundtable on prime day. Both events showcase the benefits that tech platforms provide small businesses.

Today, we will now look at this through another lens. Yes, it is true that innovation and ingenuity built this country. In fact, we could--one could argue that these qualities are uniquely American and have propelled our nation to produce the most successful companies and the foremost technologies. And I know that the companies we have on this panel and the ones we don't start it as an idea in a basement or a college dorm room, and that entrepreneurship, the spirit that built your companies is to be commended.

That being said the grip that big tech now holds over our daily lives and our competitive landscape at the same time is astounding but also concerning. Big tech platforms dominate search functions, the devices used by nearly every American, online advertising and online messaging platforms, they are market leaders in cloud computing services to businesses and consumers while also providing entertainment and other digital streaming services.

Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, Alphabet and Facebook are collectively worth over $4.3 trillion. Those five companies comprise over 15 percent of the total value of the S&P 500 which tracks the market value of the 500 largest companies listed on U.S. stock exchanges. To provide a little more context on the scope and reach of these companies, Amazon currently has approximately 50 percent of the U.S. ecommerce retail market. Nearly 90 percent of internet searches go through Google and its subsidiary YouTube while Facebook put in $55 billion in ad revenue last year and apple sold over 217 million iPhones in 2018 alone.

The sheer size of this company along with pervasive integration of these platforms and concentration of power influencing online traffic raises questions that should concern anyone who cares about market access, data privacy, small business development, entrepreneurship and innovation. And one only has to look to the decline in American start-ups to connect the dots.

In 2006, 558,000 businesses were formed but the census reported that only 414,000 businesses were studied in 2015. And there is growing anxiety not only in the U.S. but around the world that the large tech companies pose a threat to innovation and competition. When consolidation takes place in any industry, a market power is increased as it has in the tech industry. It is simply too hard for new businesses to get off the ground. Many of the popular products and features of these companies have not been developed internally. They have occurred through merger and acquisition with the largest being Microsoft pain over $26 billion for LinkedIn.

Do we want a country of entrepreneurs and investors that dream of building something or dream of being bought by larger competitors? In my view we need to reboot this start-up economy. And when small businesses do get off the ground and are able to succeed, we need to ensure that they are treated fairly on online marketplaces and that consumers can find them on search engines.

Small businesses need certainty and transparency when they are operating this--their businesses on digital platforms so that they can set competitive prices and still make enough money to continue to grow their businesses, create jobs, and invest in their communities. And when small firms do get into disputes with the powerful gatekeepers, they need a fair shot at resolving the problem so that they can continue to run their businesses.

And finally, I think we need to be clear that in a digital marketplace that every firm and especially the big (INAUDIBLE) films here today are desperate for our data. Our data is an economic asset which garners more value as one collects more of it. The concentration of the data in fewer and fewer firms has implications for small businesses. The internet and digital platforms are so deeply woven into American lives that small firms cannot afford to be excluded and/or treated unfairly.

Small businesses need to be protected by policies that offer them the certainty and transparency they need to make meaningful business decisions. As consumers continue to increase their engagement with businesses through digital platforms, small firms need to be sure that they can be found when new and existing customers are looking for their business. We cannot allow our economy to become one that stifles innovation or make it impossible for small firms to compete.

I look forward to working with my colleagues on both sides of the aisle to create meaningful policies that foster collaboration between small firms and digital platforms uninsured that small businesses have a fair opportunity to succeed. I now like to yield to the Ranking Member Mr. Chabot for his opening statement.

CHABOT: Thank you, Madam Chairwoman, and thank you for the witnesses that are here today. We understand it's not always easy to answer when Congress calls but are glad that you've taken the time out of your busy schedules to speak with us today.

The digital age has caused a revolution for small businesses. No more are small firms caught behind their larger counterparts when it comes to the availability of game-changing technologies to help grow and expand their businesses. Small firms can now utilize cutting-edge products and services to respond to market changes very swiftly. And there's--we--with the increasing adoption of mobile computing devices, cloud systems and online conference call technology like FaceTime, employees can collaborate effectively even across great distances and work almost anywhere.

But perhaps, the greatest benefit is the financial savings that affords small businesses. Increases in productivity allow companies to do more, faster, and with less overhead. Not surprisingly, many of these digital platforms have been developed and marketed by large businesses such as our witnesses today from Amazon and Google. Have there been some concerns regarding privacy and intellectual property concerns? Of course, there have. But by and large the development of these digital platform products and services from these tech giants has been a boon for the millions of individual small businesses that would probably never have existed without them.

We are the Small Business Committee here after all but we like all businesses as competition drives progress, growth, and economic expansion. Today's hearing is an opportunity for us to examine the symbiotic relationship between small firms and big businesses. Both need each other to continue our unprecedented economic expansion of the past three years. I think we're all looking forward to our discussion here this afternoon. Thank you, Madam Chair, for holding this hearing and I yield back.

VELAZQUEZ: Thank you, Mr. Chabot. The gentleman yields back and if committee members have an opening statement, we will ask that they be submitted for the record. I would like to just take a minute to explain the timing rules. Each witness gets five minutes to testify, our members get five minutes for questioning. There is a lighting system to assist you. The green light comes on when you begin and a yellow light means there is one minute--minute remaining. The red light comes on when you are out of time and we ask that you stay within that time frame to the best of your ability.

I would now like to introduce our witnesses on today's first panel. I will take a minute into--introduce each of you before turning over for testimony. Our first--first witness today is Mr. Dharmesh Mehta. Mr. Mehta is the president for Amazon customer trust and support--partner support team.

The team is focused on creating a trustworthy shopping experience across Amazon stores worldwide by protecting customers brands selling, partners and Amazon from fraud and abuse and they're also focused on providing world-class support for Amazon selling partners. He joined Amazon in October 2013 and prior to joining Amazon, Mr. Mehta spent most of his career in the technology industry in a variety of product engineering and marketing leadership roles. Welcome, sir.

Our second witness is America's--Miss Erica when--Swanson. Ms. Swanson currently serves as the head of community engaged--engagement for grow with Google which is a new U.S. initiative to help people grow their skills, careers, and businesses through free training tools and events. Previously, she served as head of community impact investments and programs at Google Fiber. She led the team responsible for developing and delivering a range of social impact investment and community engagement strategies in Google Fiber Cities. A key area of focus was partnering with local leaders to advance digital equity.

Our third witness is Dr. Joe Kennedy, a senior fellow at information technology and innovation foundation where he focuses on economic policy. For almost three decades, he has provided legal and economic advice to senior officials in the public and private sector. Much of this advice has been directed at public policies involving technology competitiveness and the social contract. Dr. Kennedy previously served as the chief economist for the U.S. Department of Commerce where he oversaw a taff--a staff of 15 economists and regularly briefed the secretary of commerce on economic issues including the financial crisis and immigration reform. Welcome home. Mr. Mehta, you are now recognized for five minutes.

MEHTA: Thank you, Chairwoman Velazquez, Ranking Member Chabot and members of the committee. My name is Dharmesh Mehta and I'm the vice president of worldwide customer trust and partner support at Amazon. Amazon's mission is to be earth's most customer centric company.

Our philosophy is simple; to work backwards from what customers want; convenience, selection and low prices, and to constantly innovate to make our store better for both our buying customers and our selling partners. Amazon lowers barriers to entry for entrepreneurs, we help make retail more vibrantly competitive and we delight customers with new innovations. In 1999, we decided to open our stores to small and medium businesses or SMBs to sell alongside us because we wanted to give customers greater selection that only third-party sellers could provide. And in 2006, we did the same with our logistics network and we invited SMBs to a new program called fulfilment by Amazon to give customers even faster delivery.

With the partnership of small, medium, businesses, we now provide our customers with even more selection with faster delivery speeds. Our store model has worked well because empowering third-party selling has created a better customer experience than Amazon could otherwise provide on its own.

Today, in the United States alone there are more than 1.9 million businesses content creators and developers that are using Amazon's products and services to realize their dreams and they are thriving. On average, they sell more than 4,000 items every minute. In 2018, there were over 25,000 entrepreneurs that surpassed $1 million in sales on Amazon.

In addition, these entrepreneurs have used these sales and their businesses to create more than 830,000 jobs for Americans. When third parties first started selling on Amazon, they generated about $100 million in sales and were about 3 percent of our total sales. Since then, we've made substantial investments to help our selling partner succeed, and now SMBs, generate about a hundred and sixty billion dollars in sales and they represent 58 percent of the total value of physical products sold in our stores. And that's because third-party sellers are thriving and growing at almost twice as fast as Amazon's own retail business and we celebrate that growth and we expect that trend to continue.

But numbers paying only part of the picture, every American small business has a story that tells much, much more and so I'd like to share one with the committee. Let me tell you about Tara Darnley from GreensboroNorth Carolina. She owns Darnley and company Tara and her husband Carl had an idea for a new product to help their baby get through teething. At the time, Tara didn't have a business background, she didn't have a college degree and her husband was working as a pastry chef.

So they started to prototype devices and a few prototypes later, Darnley and company was in business with the Yummy Mitt. Their innovative teether became a big hit at trade shows and a few months later, the Yummy Mitt was on retail shelves. However, Tara says that listing the product on Amazon was the real game-changer. Tara not only sold on Amazon but she real I--relied on Amazon customer reviews and sales data to grow her business. She said that she had initially focused on marketing to moms but as she looked at the Amazon data, she realized that grandparents were an untapped target. And Tara says that their sales really jumped when they started marketing to grandparents.

Darnley and company is now a global company. They sell 20 different baby products. Carl quit his day job. He now works for Tara every day and they have 10 employees running the business. There are thousands of stories just like this but I'd love to tell you if we had the time. We know that our selling partners have many ways to reach our customers and so our value proposition has to remain strong. That's the reason that this year we'll invest over $15 billion in infrastructure and tools and programs and employees that create programs to help our selling partner success.

We have 7,000 employees building tools and features that help our selling partners run their business to set up their accounts, to list products, to manage their inventory and to grow their business. We have another 10,000 full-time employees that are dedicated to understanding, responding to and providing support to our selling partners, and our goal is to respond to and resolve every one of those contacts expeditiously. Last year, more than 80 percent of those selling partner issues were fully resolved in less than 24 hours.

We also have 5000 employees working to prevent fraud and abuse in our stores. Our efforts to proactively stop foreign abuse are critical to creating a trusted shopping experience, not only for our customers but also for our honest selling partners. We're also proud of the work we've done to help our selling partners build thriving businesses beyond selling on Amazon. That includes hundreds of thousands of authors who have published millions of books through Kindle direct publishing, hundreds of thousands of SMBs and start-ups using Amazon Web Services and hundreds of thousands of third-party developers who built more than a hundred thousand skills for Alexa.

These opportunities enable a wide variety of entrepreneurs to sell their products, fuel their creative passion, grow their business and create jobs. I look forward to answering any questions the committee may have.

VELAZQUEZ: Thank you. Miss Swanson, you're now recognized.

SWANSON: Chairwoman Velazquez, Ranking Member Chabot and distinguished members of the committee, thank you for the opportunity to appear before you today. I appreciate your leadership in making sure small businesses has every opportunity to grow and thrive and I look forward to sharing with you the many ways that Google is committed to supporting that goal.

My name is Erica Swanson and I am the head of community engagement for grow with Google, which is Google initiative to create economic opportunity for all Americans. At Google, we are deeply proud of the ways in which we support the success of the small business community in the United States and globally and we believe large companies like Google should play a role in helping them succeed.

Today, I will discuss Google's positive economic impact on American businesses, the products and tools we provide small businesses to help them succeed and grow with Google's free trainings and programs for Americans small business owners and employees.

Google tools help American businesses find and connect with customers. In 2018, Google search and advertising tools helped provide $335 billion of economic activity nationwide over 1.3 million U.S. businesses website publishers and non-profits use our tools annually to grow their customer base and drive revenue.

Two examples of small businesses that use our products and services to grow their business and reach new customers are Propel Electric Bikes in Brooklyn, New York and Nehemiah manufacturing company in Cincinnati, Ohio. I go into more detail in my written testimony about how these inspiring businesses are using our products to succeed.

There are a number of ways our products and tools help small businesses meet their online goals. Businesses are discoverable not only in organic search, that's the standard non advertising search results but also through free business profiles on Google where businesses can list their websites, add photos, update their hours and more. In addition to free services, we have a robust suite of advertising products that help small businesses reach the right customer at the right time.

For every $1 invested in Google ads, our estimates suggest that businesses make an average of $2 back in revenue. With Google Analytics on a business website, the owner can better understand their customers to make online effort--online marketing efforts even more effective. And Google's suite of workplace productivity tools called G suite helps small businesses work more efficiently. Google also plays a part in helping small businesses reach new customers who are outside the U.S. Small business exports contribute significantly to the U.S. economy.

Market Finder is Google's free tool that enables any small business to identify the best expansion markets for their business, find shipping and logistic partners, adapt to local markets and start exporting to customers around the world. We understand that the magnitude of tools and resources available can be daunting. That's why we launched Google for small business, a dedicated online tool that curates our resources into a personalized digital marketing plan. We also help small businesses learn how to use our products and tools. Through our growth--through our grow with Google program, we are seeking to ensure that more Americans seize the opportunity that is created by technology.

Since 2017, grow with Google has trained more than three million Americans in all 50 states. We do this through our free online tools, partnerships with local organizations, delivering in-person trainings, and providing philanthropy to organizations that are helping some businesses learn skills. We also know how important it is to support small businesses that are just getting started.

So last month, as part of our $1 billion global commitment to create more economic opportunity for everyone. Google.org announced a $10 million U.S. commitment to help low-income underrepresented entrepreneurs start their businesses by providing access to training, mentoring, and much-needed capital. Our grow with Google programs continue to evolve to meet the needs of our users.

For example, just last week, we partnered with the Small Business Administration to support National Veterans Small Business Week. We also launched a series of new resources that support the 2.5 million veteran led businesses in the United States.

In conclusion, the future of small businesses online is right and we are proud of the role we play. We appreciate the opportunity to highlight Google's contributions to helping the small business community and we thank you. We look forward to your questions.

VELAZQUEZ: Thank you. Dr. Kennedy.

KENNEDY: Thank you very much Chairwoman Velazquez, Ranking Member Chabot, and members of the committee. I'm pleased to be here to talk about the impact that large internet companies are having on small business. I'd like to make five basic points in my opening statement.

The first is that large Internet platforms deliver tremendous benefits to small business. Any business now can set up a free website. But it can also set up social networking accounts for free using Facebook, Instagram, YouTube and Amazon. Not only that it can also you--use market platforms like eBay and Amazon to sell worldwide to potential customers. These platforms offer--an off--often offer a variety of other services such as handling the payments, shipping, handling returns thus saving the small business from having to do that itself.

Gig platforms match small business men and women with potential customers that are interested in their services that save, allowing them to build a clientele without spending more money on print advertising, radio or mail inserts. And finally, a separate set of platforms including Microsoft and Google offer cloud services on demand for colors--for small businesses.

My second point is that these platforms share a common interest with the small businesses that use them and that is to offer a larger variety of good products and services which will attract more consumers, which will result in more sales. Platforms that don't do this successfully will lose market share.

My third point is that this model isn't--this fundamental model isn't new. We also have large retail chains including Costco, Safeway, CVS and Walmart which offer a shelf space to thousands of suppliers. These retail shops collect a lot of data on what's selling and occasionally, they make the decision to offer a competing profit or--be competing product. That product then sits on the same shelf often with those of its other suppliers and sometimes offered at a discount.

Wherever this happens, consumers benefit. They get a broader choice and you get lower prices and this is exactly the type of competition that we should be encouraging. My fourth point is that globalization and technology have changed the optimum size of firms in many industries. Small firms feel pressure to grow in order to take advantage of a global market. But platforms relieve some of this pressure because they stand ready to take some of their fixed costs and turn them in the variable cost that can scale up or down with business conditions. And so, these include some of the ones I've mentioned; shipping returns, cloud-based--setting up cloud services.

And then my final point is that antitrust should--policy should encourage competition but it should not protect companies whether they're large or small from the effects of that competition. Are--the fundamental guideposts for com--for antitrust should remain the consumer welfare standard which looks at whether a particular merger or a business activity will harm consumers by raising price, lower in quality or delaying innovation.

Where these occur existing policy and law allows regulators and potential plaintiffs to take action to rectify the situation. But we should not use antitrust policy to try and accomplish other goals such as instilling privacy requirements or doing--trying to rebalance the political power between large or small companies. With that, I'll conclude my statement and I want to thank you again for this opportunity to talk to you and I look forward to your questions. Thank you.

VELAZQUEZ: Thank you, Dr. Kennedy and thank you all for your testimonies. I will begin by recognizing myself for five minutes and I would like to address my first question to you Mr. Mehta. Some argue that Amazon doesn't just dominate the online market. It controls it access by creating a platform for sellers while also competing against those on--those same businesses.

Doesn't a company that sells things and owns the platform where things are sold have an inherent advantage over other small businesses that it's competing against?

MEHTA: Thank you, Chairwoman. First, we're holding this hearing and allowing Amazon to participate in this conversation. You know, I'm honored to be here. Let me address your question by comparing ourselves to what happens traditionally in the retail market. And when we talk about retail, we talk about the overall retail market. Amazon represents about 1 percent of the worldwide retail market, about 4 percent of the U.S. retail market.

And whether you look at Walmart or Target or Trader Joe's or Costco, all of these major retailers have a private label business that competes with others in their store. For Amazon, our private label business represents about 1 percent of our total sales. If you look at most of these retailers their private label businesses represent anywhere from 18 to 85 percent of their total sales.

VELAZQUEZ: I hear you. However, there--there--there are some research that shows that Amazon's own product consistently win the buy box and we know what it's winning the buy box. The area on the right hand, side of the page that says up to Cart. So this to me suggests that the buy box is designed to favor Amazon and potentially gives you an--an unfair advantage. But I have a lot of questions so let me proceed.

Ms. Swanson, like Amazon, Google has market dominance in that 90 percent of all internet searches go through Google. Small businesses cannot survive on the internet if they cannot be found. However, when Amazon, Walmart, Verizon, Expedia and many more large companies spend millions advertising on Google and their ads appear on the first page, doesn't this crowd out the ability for small firms to advertise online?

SWANSON: Thank you, Madam Chairwoman, for having us here and an opportunity to have this conversation. There are a number of ways that small businesses can be discovered online and at Google, we are proud to provide a range of options, both paid unpaid. We have a suite of tools that are free at no cost for small business--

VELAZQUEZ: And--and--and so, if you Google a restaurant that doesn't pay but is using your free space, that restaurant probably will show up on page five or seven and so they--that clearly gives an advantage for those who pay and that will show up in the first page.

SWANSON: There are a number of ways that small businesses like this small restaurant could appear depending on the particular search query whether that search query included the restaurant's name. But typically, if it includes the restaurant name or--or a qualifier like near me, it will appear in the--the first organic search listing.

VELAZQUEZ: How can entrepreneurs optimize their search results? Does Google Maps only identify restaurants and hotels on its mapping platform for those businesses that are willing to pay to be found?

SWANSON: No, Madam Chairman--Chairwoman, we have a number of ways that small businesses can appear on Google search and maps, many of those are free. So for example grow with Google help small businesses claim their free Google my business listing. This allows a small business to share their website or if they don't have one create a website so that they show up in that local search on that map.

They can share their hours; they can share customer reviews encourage that conversation with customers that's so important to building customer loyalty over time.

VELAZQUEZ: Mr. Mehta, small businesses just want to be treated fairly and understand Amazon's Terms of Use regarding pricing, fees and other arrangements. Is it true that for some businesses, 30 through 40 percent of their sales prices--their sales price goes back to Amazon?

MEHTA: Chairwoman, the--the way our fees work for professional sellers on Amazon, they pay $40 a month here in the U.S. And then on top of that, they will pay a fee that depends on the product they sell, typically eight to 15 percent. Any additional fees are up to the seller based on additional services they choose to use such as our fulfilment services or advertising services.

VELAZQUEZ: Do you have a number as to the percentage that they pay back to Amazon compared to the profits that they're making?

MEHTA: Madam Chairwoman, I do not have that data point in front of me. I'd be happy to have the team follow up.

VELAZQUEZ: Does--does Amazon gives sellers adequate notice and transparency of changes to fees or other terms of their seller agreement?

MEHTA: Our fees are publicly posted, they're both available to all sellers before they start selling as well as anyone in the public can see those fees and we try to provide transparent advance notice before changing those fees--

VELAZQUEZ: You try to provide but do you in advance?

MEHTA: Madam Chairwoman, I don't own our fees. I'm happy to have someone follow up at the specifics of what's been done in every instance. But we want our sellers to be able to plan for our fees and we try to make those fees very attractive. You know, for instance if I look at our fulfilment by Amazon fees that provide fulfilment cell--services for sellers, we benchmark those versus alternatives that the sellers have. And our fees on average are 50 to 80 percent lower than sellers' alternatives.

VELAZQUEZ: Well, what I'm asking you in--in the name of transparency and certainty for the small businesses is do you provide notices in advance giving them enough time? What about sellers that use Amazon warehouses. Do they have opportunities to reconcile if there is a dispute with Amazon and prevent their inventory from being seized?

MEHTA: Absolutely. So when sellers send their inventory into our fulfilment centers, if they choose to use fulfilled by Amazon, they have visibility into their inventory; that inventory that's available for sale, when it's purchased. And if for any reason there's a dispute, we have 10,000 associates that support sellers every day, I mean respond to them quickly.

VELAZQUEZ: Does Amazon consider how long a seller has been using the platform before closing or suspending an account?

MEHTA: When we close or suspend accounts, they can be done for a variety of reasons. If a count is suspended for potential fraud or abuse or other policy violations, we--we make decisions around closing accounts based on the activities that have happened in the potential policy violations.

VELAZQUEZ: Thank you. Now, I recognize the Ranking Member.

CHABOT: Thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. Mehta, in March, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in partnership with Amazon published a report detailing the impact of technology on rural communities. The report acknowledges that rural business owners who have already embraced digital technology are seeing tremendous results. What's been your experience in seeing the potential of e-commerce for growth by small businesses in rural America?

MEHTA: Thank you, Ranking Member Chabot, for the question. It's a great question. you know, one of the powerful things that enabling sellers to sell in Amazon store has achieved is for these businesses that are often in rural America that have historically set up physical shops and they've only been able to reach customers within a small distance of their physical store. By selling on Amazon, we enable them to not only sell in their local district, but to sell across their state, to sell across the country, and increasingly sell across the world.

You know, as one example a feature we launched recently called FBA export is a program for sellers that use our fulfilment services to export products to other parts of the world. It helps sellers find customers in other parts of the world, helps navigate export requirements. I mean, that just one program generated $1.8 billion in sales for American businesses.

CHABOT: Thank you very much. Ms. Swanson, I'll go to you next. It's my understanding at about 96 percent of the people that occupy this globe are outside the borders of the United States, so there's a huge market out there for large and small businesses. And I've got a book here of growing small business exports by Google, and could you tell us obviously, we don't have time to go through all this, but what it--what is Google able to do to allow America's small businesses to more successfully market their products the globe?

SWANSON: Thank you, Ranking Member Chabot. Being able to increase broader markets is increasingly important to small businesses. My family had a small business, a bakery in a small town and their market was their town. And today, a small business like that can reach and sell across the nation and across the globe. This is important to our economy. And--and to job creation in the United States, one recent study shows that six million jobs in the United States are--are supported by small businesses who are exporting.

Google is proud to make it easier for small businesses to export their goods and to find new markets. Examples are--are straighter sports in South Dakota. They had this great little idea to build bikes that little kids could push without needing pedals so they can move without falling over. They have this great idea and now thanks to digital tools and the expanded market that the web enables, they've sold two and a half million bikes in 78 countries and the majority of their sales are coming from international exports.

This is--this is really enabled because the market has--because the web has enabled small businesses to reach into these global markets to find new places to reach new customers.

CHABOT: Thank you. Mr. Kennedy--Dr. Kennedy, I'm sorry. Some have suggested recently that we need a new regulatory regime to clamp down on tech companies and that the government ought to be determining, you know, what you do and how you do it etc, to a much greater degree than is existent today. Obviously, these are private companies but we also, you know, want them to--to be fair, you know, with the public and that sort of thing. What is your view relative to additional regulations coming out of Washington? Mike.

KENNEDY: Thank you. I tend to be very skeptical of that. I think that the--the government's primary purpose should be to try and ensure a competitive market and to try and make sure that there's active competition that results in good products at low prices going to consumers. It--it should be reluctant to take aside in the various battles that occur between businesses over different practices or the--the--you know, getting market share, the one exception is where there are is either a merger that could result in monopoly power or where there are clear uncompetitive practices.

And there I think the existing antitrust laws already give regulators and potential plaintiffs the bit--with--the powers that they need to restore competition. I do think it's worth having an--a dialogue about fair business practices in general in transparency and consistency. But I'm very reluctant to have the government mandate those. I think it's--your--it's likely be more productive if that if decisions are arrived at by in an open conversation.

CHABOT: Thank you very much. My time is expired, Madam Chair.

VELAZQUEZ: If you have any other question, you are free. The Chair recognizes Ms. Davids from Kansas.

DAVIDS: Thank you, Chairwoman, and--and Ranking Member Chabot, for holding this hearing today and I think this is a really important conversation as it relates to--to our country small businesses. Finding a fair market place than competing with big businesses has always been a challenge for small businesses. And using and competing with tech large--text--tech companies however is a--a new iteration on that issue.

So it's vital that we ensure that online marketplaces provide a fair online space for businesses to compete and I actually, I'm going to follow up on the Ranking Member's line of questioning because that's where I was headed anyway. So mister--sorry Dr. Kennedy, I noticed in your testimony and you actually started getting to it based on Ranking Member Chabot's questioning is can you talk to a little bit--talk to us a little bit about enhancing the rules governing fairness and transparency as it relates to how small businesses can interact with these large platforms that in some instances, they're both a customer and a competitor of the large platforms?

KENNEDY: Yeah, I can't--I don't feel I can get into a lot of detail but I used to be a general counsel of the Senate Subcommittee on investigations. And then, we found that when we saw a problem in a particular market, often if we called people in and we had a quiet discussion with them about why they did a certain thing and we could get a sensible resolution. And, you know, they--they would go off and amend their practice and I think that kind of informal dialogue can accomplish a lot.

I think as far as specific things, in general, I think it's--it's reasonable for a business man to know what the rules are for a platform and to have them applied with some consistency. And--and as a general manner, I'd--I'd look at Costco or Walmart and I'd look and see how are they treating their suppliers and we don't seem to have a lot of problems with them.

So, you know, if they have a particular practice, if Amazon and Google has a similar practice, I don't think necessarily we should have a problem with them either. I do note--I forget the gentleman's name but one of the people on the next panel has in his filed testimony some pretty good discussion of some of the issues and possible resolutions. So I think they're, you know, they're out there.

DAVIDS: In your testimony, you talked about the--an example of the United Kingdom's open banking initiative and the EU's payment services directive. Can you talk a little bit about that and why you use that as an example?

KENNEDY: Well, I don't know--I don't know that--the great details are in them but in general they allow--my understanding is that they allow a banking customer to mandate that his infamy--his or her information be available to--to various outside apps.

So that if you want to download an app that will download information from your say banking account and compare your fees to the fees of other banks and tell you how you could save on fees by moving to a different bank or--

DAVIDS: So you think those--those kinds of policies might be helpful when we're talking about large internet platforms that are--are selling goods and services and having a very transparent process of understanding what your fees are versus if you are on--if you were paying for Google to put you in a search versus another searching platform, I'm actually not sure what--what other platforms folks use besides Google which kind of brings us to the point of how--how dependent small businesses might be on one or two specific platforms.

Do you think that that--that's something that we need to see more of in these instances?

KENNEDY: I think in general it is good to have a conversation with between Congress and the industries. It often is better to have it in--in private where people can, you know, don't feel under the gun that they have to get every word exactly right. And--and, you know, and I--I think that often that results in reasonable changes to business practices, you know, the--the platforms already have a strong interest--

DAVIDS: My--my--my time is--my time is running out. I think I think the folks in my district might be a little surprised to hear you say that we should have meetings behind closed doors with large businesses. But I thank you for your time and thank you for your testimony today. I yield back.

VELAZQUEZ: Gentlelady yields back and the gentleman from Oklahoma Mr. Hern, ranking member of the Subcommittee on economic growth, tax on capital access is recognized.

HERN: Thank you, Madam Chairwoman. As you all know, every big business begins as a small business and as an entrepreneur or business owner, a job creator of thousands of jobs over 34 years, I appreciate the support that you've given the small business job creators of the world. I was just looking, I have five businesses that I created that my family members now run today. Thanks, being in Congress that use both of your services, either Google Suites, or the AWSS3 server system and cloud-based, other tools that you have. So I really appreciate it.

And for Amazon, this support is represented by 500 million of AWS credits that you gave out in 2018. This has led to hundreds of thousands of small businesses start-ups using your web services to launch a scale your business--their businesses including over a million current small businesses utilizing their web services, 6,500 of which are in my home state of Oklahoma. As for Google, the support for small business is represented by the fact that in 2018, your search and advertising tools help to provide 335 billion of economic activity nationwide, 712 million of economic activity in Oklahoma and 1.69 million of free advertising the Oklahoma non-profits, benefits for over 7,800 Oklahoma businesses website publishers and non-profits and we thank you for that.

This--both of you all are very well represented in our northeast Oklahoma area. The Google Data Center complex is just outside of my district which is--have had the opportunity to tour which I'm going the record for say it's very large. The Amazon Fulfilment Center coming to Tulsa in 2020 is the largest ever job employer ever in the history of northeast Oklahoma where we're at. So I really appreciate that.

So with all of this, I would say that what you do also for--for the helping start small businesses start up and help with the--the protecting a small business from cyber threats, I would like for you just taking my remaining amount of time here so hopefully a min and a half each that each of you could talk about how beneficial these start-up services are and ability to continue on with your marketplace. We'll start with Amazon, your marketplace and cyber threats as we're seeing today, how you can help secure those fronts for--for small business and entrepreneurs.

MEHTA: Thank you, congressman. You know, absolutely, one of the things that we find to be very powerful for these small businesses is the way that we can level the playing field, that we can provide access to not only the reach of hundreds of millions of customers, not only the large fulfilment centers and fulfilment capability we've built, but also the advanced Fraud and Abuse detection capabilities that protect the small and medium businesses that end up lowering costs for them and then going to continue to allow them to thrive. And we think it's some of the key ingredients that have continued to allow small businesses to grow so fast and become now 58 percent of our total sales.

HERN: Thank you Ms. Swanson--Dr. Swanson--Ms. Swanson, I'm sorry.

SWANSON: Still Ms. Thank you, Congressman Hern. we're really--Google is really proud to call Oklahoma home and--and pleased to hear that we have customers in your family. Cloud computing--cloud--cloud computing is one of the ways that we help small businesses take their security very seriously. Cloud computing can give small businesses an advantage that--that--that wasn't available many years ago. It can help them access their data from anywhere, anytime at a reasonable price and security and--and that safety is really built.

And what we hear as we travel the country working with small businesses is that they're really good at what they do, they know their business. What they might not know as much about is the digital tools things like how to keep their data safe and so they--they turn to affordable products like cloud computing to keep their data safe.

HERN: I appreciate both of your comments. The only thing I'd like to say in my remaining mini--moments is I think sometimes, people forget that every large business did start as a small business. And I think we often times forget, in the case of both your companies for sure and--and obviously Mr. Zuckerberg who's not here, your companies were started by the people who are currently involved in your companies and we just ask I think collectively as a bipartisan committee that they not forget where they came from. Whether it be Mr. brand and Mr. Page in their dorm room at Stanford or whether it be Mr. Bezos who I'd like to go on the record to say his first job was at McDonald's at 16 years old somewhere near and dear to my heart, and learned a lot from that lesson that they wouldn't forget and, you know, continue to help entrepreneurs create this competitive environment in the free market ideas that got them the ability to start and allow them to get to where they're at today that they would not forget that.

And if that's a message that we could get collectively bipartisan out of this committee back to them and many of the other companies that have come from absolutely nothing, we'd like to make that message heard loud and clear. Thank you. I yield back.

VELAZQUEZ: Gentleman yields back and now we recognize Mr. Evans from Pennsylvania and vice chair of the committee.

EVANS: Thank you. Thank you, Madam Chair, and I thank you for the leadership on this discussion because I like to start out with just a title. It--basically, the title is, a fair playing field; investing big tech impact on small business. I like to start out with I think is his name, Mr. Kennedy. Is that you?

KENNEDY: Yes.

EVANS: You were kind of given a general sense of what certain things you didn't think should happen in terms of what governments should do and here. So you--you see that question, it's a very simple question. So kind of give me your reaction to that question that we are just attempting to do our oversight responsibilities, you know, we know the importance of small business in this nation and the role that it plays.

I come from the city of Philadelphia. We have like 25 percent poverty. I like to see more growth, more opportunity. So can you talk a little bit about relating to what you see is the fair playing field because what I heard you mention as a solution was kinda using a soft stick of conversation. So talk a little bit to me about how you view a fair playing field.

KENNEDY: So--so I--I think the government should work hard to make sure that it is easy to start a business as--as--as possible, that it is easy to get credit and a, you know, consulting help is as possible. That when a business does create it--get created, that it, you know, the markets it is in is are competitive and give it a fair shot, that, you know, that the rules of the market, the laws are, you know, fairly applied.

But it shouldn't try and favor one set of businesses over the other whether they're small--small businesses versus big business or platforms versus sellers. It should allow that competition to go on and, you know, that competition inevitably results in losers who complain. But unless there's, you know, demonstrated unfairness in the rules of the market in which case, antitrust already has the powers to deal with it, the government, you know, should leave well a lot--well enough alone.

EVANS: Well, if you were whipping out your report card at this point and you look at where we are, and obviously this is new to all of us. I mean, we're just fully trying to understand it. But, you know, we hear a lot of complaints about individuals not being able to get into the marketplace as you say government should just leave it like it is, then what are you rating it at this point?

KENNEDY: Well, I think the--the company is testifying today and the other ones we've mentioned, they already have a--a significant interest in expanding the number of small businesses that used--and big businesses that use their platform and if working with those businesses--businesses to grow, you know, to grow their volume. So that--that incentive already exists.

Now, there's (INAUDIBLE) at the margin about this rule or that rule or how its applied and I think, you know, government usually doesn't--it is better off not getting too involved in setting those rules but, you know, should concentrate on is the competition on the whole fair.

EVANS: But would you agree you may, you may not, would you agree that it is critical that small businesses are given an equal opportunity to enter the marketplace and flourish?

KENNEDY: Yes.

EVANS: okay. Well, I guess that's why I was kind of trying to drill down on a question in, you know, what--what's your view of because obviously, you know, maybe some cases, it may not be working.

KENNEDY: Yeah. and I think the central question antitrust officials ought to ask is--is what's going on hurting the customer? So if--if--if competition is--is putting some companies out of business but prices are going down, efficiency is going up, consumers are benefiting, then that--that's okay. If consumers are getting hurt because companies are getting monopoly power and they're raising prices, then that's not okay and we have antitrust policies. But we ought to look at how is the consumer being helped to hurt.

EVANS: Thank you and I yield back the balance of my time.

VELAZQUEZ: Gentleman yields back. The gentleman from Minnesota Mr. Hagedorn is recognized for five minutes.

HAGEDORN: Thank you, Madam Chair and Ranking Member Chabot. I appreciate the witnesses. I--I represent a rural part of southern Minnesota there and so obviously for small businesses and entrepreneurs wanting to get their start, the platforms that you provide can make a--a huge difference. They haven't in many instances so, you know, especially from a rural standpoint, I get it and I think as my colleague congressman Hern said, in many ways, this is--this really good thing.

But I did too with someone in my office recently. Mr. Metha (PH) about a product that a woman named Sophia had on your platform. She's selling espresso machines, had about a hundred thousand put into the business, very happy because doing it through you she can work from home and all sorts of kind of you'd say luxuries for a business owner to be able to--to be able to do those types of things.

But she said there were certain costs, you know, 15 percent on average goes to your company to sell their machines there could be storage costs if you have machines at the warehouses and things like that, and also some advertising. So in general, do you think the way that you're charging these small businesses is fair? Are there ways to look at that to make sure that they're not being gouged? How would you respond to that?

MEHTA: Congressman, thank you for the question. You know, fundamentally, the way we view this is that we succeed when sellers succeed our growth over the years, a large part of it is because of the success of these small, medium businesses. And so, we want to make sure we offer a set of services at a set of fees and prices that are super attractive and reasonable.

Now, advertising as one of those can be very powerful for that rural business that has an unknown brand that no one may know about that maybe has invented an amazing espresso maker. We want them to be able to advertise their products but advertising is a choice. I mean, for the brand that is known and is generating the sales or the awareness that they want, they don't need to buy advertising.

And so, we try and make as many of these a choice a simple choice with easy-to-use tools so that different small medium businesses can pick the set of services that work best for them.

HAGEDORN: Yeah, that's a very good answer, it makes sense. You want your clients to be successful and from a consumer standpoint, it's awesome for us to be able to go there and wherever it is and find all these different choices and--and shop and--and things of that nature.

So then, I would move on to the--the other aspect of this which is kind of the infrastructure of how we search for companies that can provide services and products. So I'd go to the Swanson. How do we know for sure that your company isn't picking winners and losers in the marketplace that you don't--you're not really fronting for companies that may advertise more or, you know, just in general how can we be assured that that's not happening because you're the infrastructure, you're like the road and if you just decide that only certain cars and trucks get to go out first or get to drive faster and everybody else is left behind, that wouldn't be fair. So in this case, with the internet, how would you respond to that?

SWANSON: Thank you congressman for the question. A Google search we--we build, we design for everyone, the business model of search is dependent on being useful and being trustworthy for our users. So we have a natural long-term incentive to prevent--to prevent that type of--of activity on our platforms.

We--we build those--those platforms and that those products in a really neutral way and--and we work hard to make sure that we're continuing to improve search to surface the most reliable most--were most reliable most relevant answers for our search users in real time.

HAGEDORN: Who--who audits you to determine whether or not that's happening because you don't know what you don't see, right? So if I put in a search for widgets but some company, it doesn't come up how would I ever know that? So who would--who would kind of look over your shoulder to make sure that that's--that's being done properly?

SWANSON: Yeah, we have a series of processes and safeguards in place that allow us to continue to test and then evolve and improve the way that search functions, some of the ways we do that for example are running hundreds of thousands of experiments every year and asking independent search users to review the quality of those--those search improvements, always looking to understand are we providing the most relevant reliable answers to our search users. We take that feedback into account; we take it very seriously.

HAGEDORN: Yeah, I'm not always for too much regulation in the marketplace and things like that. I think we should make sure that in the future, there's at least somebody who's overseeing this or looking at the results to make sure that if it--if it's not happening then we have to make some changes because I think you would want to be the first ones to make changes so the government wouldn't move in and regulate in these areas.

But it's pretty important I think for businesses and the consumers that--that--that be done on a fair basis. Thank you.

VELAZQUEZ: The gentleman yields back and the gentleman from Maine, Mr. Golden, chairman of the Subcommittee on contracting and infrastructure recognized.

GOLDEN: Thank you, Madam Chair. Mr. Mehta, I want to ask, does Amazon use algorithms that favor sellers over--who use fulfilment by Amazon over those who choose to do fulfilment by merchants?

MEHTA: Thank you, congressman, for the question. The short answer is no. We design our algorithms for search and the products we feature based on what we think customers want regardless whether those products are sold in Amazon--

GOLDEN: Just to be clear, not products but sellers.

MEHTA: We don't design them to favor sellers or products based on who's selling them or the fulfilment Channel. We designed them to prioritize what we think customers want most.

GOLDEN: All right. I guess, you know, we are--we've heard from some people back home in Maine who are concerned that that may not be the case and perhaps, you know, you have a better explanation. But has Amazon never been willing to maybe do some third-party testing or something on its algorithms which of course would be done to avoid revealing how the precise mechanisms work but could confirm for--for sellers that there is in fact no--no biased or people who use one or--or the other?

MEHTA: Yeah. so I have to have someone from our search team follow up but I do know we run constant experiments looking at our search results to make sure we're prioritizing what customers want most and that we're avoiding any type of unintentional bias in that system, and we'd have to have that team follow up with you.

GOLDEN: I would appreciate that very much and obviously, that would be important to--to avoid that kind of a unfair bias and, you know, we--we have a company in Maine that sells products to help keep houses from losing heat in the wintertime. They choose to ship their own orders and believe that they've noticed that their product has started missing out on search placement and sales to competitors who use FBA.

They believe their experience is backed up by testimony from the Institute for local self-reliance out of July house antitrust subcommittee hearing and a letter to Congress from another seller described in a November 8th Bloomberg article. You know, another concern but we have that impacts sellers ability to choose whether or not they want to use FBA instead of going with their own option is that sometimes, Amazon may suspend sellers accounts if they deliver items late.

I understand you're--you're trying to look out for consumers but I also understand that you may exempt sellers who use FBA from similar penalties. I'm just curious, is there a penalty to Amazon itself under FBA for--for late delivery that would either recompensate the--the seller or the consumer similar to the way that the people who do fulfilment by merchant?

MEHTA: Thank you, congressman. Yeah, if an order is delivered late by our fulfilment services, Amazon takes responsibility for that order, make sure the customer is made whole and we do not hold sellers liable for that. So we do take accountability for this. All right, good, good it just seems like a comment. You know, if you're going to hold--hold yourself to the standard, you would hold other--you know, well some of your clients do. That would be important. I appreciate that.

If I could shift over to Ms. Swanson, I think we're going to hear some testimony from the second panel and I do have some concerns I'm just curious in--in learning more about it having to do with some of Google's blue book, a room button changes and also some potential changes recently this year having to do with how people are able to find businesses, phone numbers.

And I think one of the, you know, you probably heard many questions about the blue button, you know, in a system where-essentially people are often booking whether they know it or not through OTAs.

GOLDEN: You know, you may have a consumer seeking to--to purchase a room directly from a--a hotel or a bed and breakfast or something and--and largely unaware that they are booking through an OTA when they use the blue book button. I'm curious if you have any feedback about that change? Have you considered whether or not you can build in the ability for consumers to choose to go directly to a business? And--and secondly, I've heard that there's been changes this year where a lot of searches no longer have phone numbers for businesses directly listed unless they opt to pay for--for that listing, essentially paying to have their own phone number, advertised and of course, as a consumer, very frustrating to think you've booked directly with someone then try and pick up the phone and call them and realize you can't.

SWANSON: Thank you, Congressman, for your question. There are a number of ways that a user might go about finding a service provider, for example, a hotel, could be to direct navigate to that website, could be to search for it, could discover it in organic search, or could choose to book through an OTA. You ask about some of those panels that we have on the right side of search. We--we do work to make it very transparent to the user. When they have the option of booking through the official site. There's a little button there that says the official site for example of that hotel, although some users may choose to book through an OTA for their own--own personal kind of shopping preferences and that's a choice that we want to--to provide.

You also asked a little bit about how to--how small businesses can make their phone number available. We know that's really important be able to provide that direct connection from search to a small business can be a critical way of initiating contact with that potential customer and through our local services, features, and products we can help small businesses list their phone numbers for free and their Google My Business listing, direct that call directly to that small business.

GOLDEN: Thank you. I appreciate that. I'm overdue on time. But I would just ask that you commit yourself to that transparency for consumers and particularly as you need to change your--your interface for things like this smaller screens, suddenly that transparency becomes much more difficult for consumers.

VELAZQUEZ: The gentlemen, yields back, and the gentleman from Ohio, Mr. Balderson, ranking member of the subcommittee on innovation and workforce development is recognized for five minutes.

BALDERSON: Thank you, Madam Chair. Thank you all for being here.

I'm going to do a couple questions and kind of follow someone Mr. Hern's lead and I'll probably try to work with you some more but--you know, it's good for us to find out--you know, the technology side of the companies and American small businesses and I'm going to share more success side of it but Mr. Mehta and Ms. Swanson. Sorry, bad angle here.

I--I first want to thank you both and your companies to date. In the district and in the state of Ohio, Amazon has invested $5 billion. And Google, you have invested closer to $7 billion. So thank you both very much.

And I want to share a story. I did the groundbreaking ceremony for Google a couple of weeks ago. And I was pulling in the facility and I was driving and I'd look off to the side, I see one of my buddies, he's got waste dumpsters there. There was nine of them. I counted. So I got excited for him. I thought, wow, Google's actually working with small businesses here in the district and the--the communities. I know how important that was so I call Seth up and I say, "Hey, Seth, congratulations, man. I'm looking at your dumpsters here on. I see nine of them out here." And he said, "Nine. He said they're better be 14." I said, "Well, we'll cross that bridge when we come to it."

(LAUGHTER)

But anyway, so just thank you because that's meaningful to small business owners in those districts when you build these huge data centers. So thank you very much. Would each of you please explain to this committee what the growth of the internet and--and the information age has meant for small businesses?

Ms. Swanson, ladies first.

SWANSON: Thank you, Congressman, for the--for the question and--and thank you for the kind words about our data centers. What you saw as part of a $13 billion investment that Google is making across America to--to create new data centers and expand our offices. And we're committed to working with small businesses in--in these communities. As part of that work.

We really see the internet and--and Google products and tools as--as--as being great equalizers as--as being tools that help small businesses, do things, reach customers, and become discoverable in ways that used to be only available to the very biggest of businesses. It used to be that if you were a small business and you wanted to market to customers, you had few options. They were TV, they were radio, maybe--maybe outdoor, out of home in some way. And now if you're a small business, you can set your budget and with very limited budget even make really effective, focused online media advertising campaigns.

And--and we here that's a game changer as we travel the country. We hear from small businesses again and again that this is helping them find the right customer at the right time, in ways that they could not have imagined before.

BALDERSON: Okay, thank you.

I--I want to jump to another question because from time limit that we're on here and because I do want to talk about the positive things that are created from tech, big techs and from small businesses.

I'd like to highlight a recent meeting that I had with a constituent of my district, who actually, I wouldn't say went out of business but pretty much just shut down his business that he had prior to that. In doing so then he changed and started up another business, a vintage bookseller business and he used Amazon's tools and including the fulfillment by Amazon. And his business just in the last year has grown 500 percent. He's had to expand his workforce. And he now shifts to customers across the U.S. and Canada.

Would you--both of you--and, Mr. Mehta, you can go first on this one would--would you--each of you please tell this committee how many businesses, publishers, or nonprofits benefit from your services that you're aware of?

MEHTA: Yeah, thank you, Congressman, for the question. And--and that story of vintage book art company is another awesome story of many entrepreneurs and small businesses across America. You know, currently, there's more than 1.9 million small businesses, content creators, authors, etc, that are small and medium businesses across the U.S. that are partnering with Amazon and growing as a result and--and interestingly, these small businesses have generated more than 830,000 new jobs for Americans. And so we're very excited both about that specific business but in general about what we've been able to do together with partnership with small businesses.

BALDERSON: Thank you both very much for your investment in Ohio and Madam Chair, I yield back my remaining time.

VELAZQUEZ: The gentleman yields back and now the gentleman from New York, Mr. Espaillat is recognized for five minutes.

ESPAILLAT: Thank you, Madam Chair.

My question goes to Mr. Mehta. I want to touch base on the Amazon storefronts. Small businesses, approximately 30,000 small and medium-sized businesses you mentioned in your prepared statement participate in Amazon storefront. My question is, what is Amazon's practice for outreach? And do you know the demographic or geographic break--break down are participating small and medium-sized businesses?

MEHTA: Thank you, Congressman, for the question. You know, Amazon storefronts is very exciting. We have 30,000 small businesses already participating. They've reached 70 million customers and sold over 250 million items. We have a number of different ways we try and outreach to these small-medium businesses. It starts with a great deal of online content and help.. Programs like our Seller University that provide courses and training and videos and webinars to help the small-medium businesses. And just recently, we announced a new Amazon Small Business Academy where we send Amazon employees into local communities to sit side by side with small businesses as they get started on Amazon and help them as they start selling. So very excited about storefronts and very excited about Small Business Academy.

ESPAILLAT: And when Amazon--when an Amazon search for product yields a result, are these products shown contemporaneously with relevant products or how does that work?

MEHTA: So when a customer places a search result on Amazon--

ESPAILLAT: --Yes--

MEHTA: --we use the query that they typed in to try and find what we think will be the best products regardless of who's selling it or how they're selling it but what we think the customers most likely to want and we put those in front of the customer.

ESPAILLAT: And--and do the results delineate Amazon storefront and those that are not? Is this the same for English-language searches versus Spanish searches or other non-English languages? How--how is that handled? If I was to search in Spanish, for example?

MEHTA: Yeah. So customers speak many different languages and we try and support them in their native language. And so when we design our search results, we do think about who the customer is and where they're searching and customize the search results accordingly.

ESPAILLAT: Okay, my next question is regarding--what is your reimbursement schedule or model for products sold through or on--on Amazon for small businesses? Is it uniform or can the vendor work to address or meet the needs of the industry? Let's say for example, seasonal, or employee design? Small businesses obviously have a very strong constraints very often. How do you handle your reimbursement schedule?

MEHTA: Thank you, Congressman, for the question. On average, our selling partners are paid seven days after a customer receives the product. And so--and we like to make that very quick as soon as after the customer receives the product.

ESPAILLAT: Thank you so much. I yield back my time.
